[Big Bad Ensemble](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadEnsemble): They share this role with Sephiroth a majority of the game, however…
[Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe): They’re the lesser of the two threats and Sephiroth is eventually the last threat AVALANCHE has to face to save the planet.

[Corporate Warfare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorporateWarfare): Shinra has a private army consisting of various types of military troopers, genetically-augmented SOLDIER members, and a wide array of robots and mecha.

[Didn't Think This Through](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntThinkThisThrough): Giving Professor Hojo free reign to work as he pleased, Shinra loved the idea of [the SOLDIER Program](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperSoldier) that would turn ordinary people into loyal superhuman combatants that could tear down enemy forces like a hot knife through butter. Then all of their best SOLDIER, including every single First-Class, [betrayed or abandoned them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere) and crippled the power of the company in the long-term, with most of their replacements not holding a candle to the originals.

[Ecocidal Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EcocidalAntagonist): Before the main conflict shifts to Sephiroth as antagonist, the central villains for the bulk of the game are the Shinra Corporation — a [MegaCorp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MegaCorp) whose business model is built upon pumping the Materia (magical life blood of the planet's biosphere) out of the environment, converting it into electricity, and selling it to the desperate masses populating the industrial hellscape of Midgard. Accordingly, the protagonists are a plucky band of eco-terrorists doing their utmost to sabotage Shinra's businesses. When they leave Midgard for a while, the full ramifications of Shinra's actions are shown on the overworld map in the giant polluted wasteland that surrounds Midgard — an ugly blot on an otherwise relatively verdant continent.

[The Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmpire): This is what they actually are and operate as. With their military (with SOLDIER doing the heavy lifting), by the time of the beginning of the game they've managed to conquer and rule a good portion of Gaia after their victory over Wutai. Even one of the 1997 commercials for [Final Fantasy VII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII) refers to them as such.
[Evil, Inc.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilInc): Very few moral people work within Shinra's walls, and the few that do tend to end up leaving the company, like Gast and Lucrecia.
[Evil Tower of Ominousness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilTowerOfOminousness): Their headquarters is a 70-story skyscraper towering over Midgar.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): Besides Reeve and Rufus and [maybe Palmer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil), the entire rest of the executive chain as well as the research departments of Shinra are so horrifically bankrupt on any sense of morality that it's easier to just sum up the trope here than in their individual entries. There's a reason why *none of them* have any notable redeeming values, and why all of them are either presumed dead or disappeared, and why Rufus simply does not lift a finger to try finding any survivors again. Hojo is the sole exception of getting his own entry [for a variety of reasons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain) that singlehandedly make him *the absolute worst of the lot.*

[Incompetence, Inc.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IncompetenceInc): Once AVALANCHE manages to really make some headway and Sephiroth [takes out the President](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice), it becomes real obvious that Shinra just isn't equipped for an actual threat. Most of their remaining SOLDIER are nowhere near as powerful as they used to be, and the rest of their leadership struggle to even gain any footing against their overwhelming problems as a small [Ragtag Bunch of Misfits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RagtagBunchOfMisfits) ruins all of their plans thoroughly; the only threat they pose usually happens when something larger incapacitates the party. Even with Hojo's amazing research, he inevitably turns on them and nearly ends the world, too. There's a reason why Rufus and Reeve end up going their own ways without attempting to recreate Shinra properly after its collapse.

[The Man Behind the Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMonsters): Every antagonist in the *Final Fantasy VII* universe can be linked back to them, as it was their discovery of Jenova that allowed scientists like Hojo and Hollander to create beings like Sephiroth and Genesis, and their mako reactors are the reason the planet is in such a miserable state due to draining the lifestream to refine into energy.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): According to Yoshinori Kitase, the word "Shinra" derives from the word "myth" in Japanese (神話, shinwa) tying into how Shinra, and many people associated with them, were all about becoming gods and controlling everything.
[Megacorp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Megacorp): They're a power company that runs Midgar, builds and maintains their own personal army, and manufactures numerous consumer products.

[One Nation Under Copyright](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneNationUnderCopyright): They rule Midgar in practice but not name, since the city actually has a mayor, who lampshades he's powerless and Shinra is the one running things. They also have a dominating influence over the rest of the world, since most towns use mako reactors to sustain themselves and Shinra has the military might to conquer them by force if anyone felt like trying to rise against them.

[The Remnant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRemnant): Following the events of *VII*, Shinra barely exists anymore — its executive board are all dead aside from Reeve (who founds his own group, the World Regenesis Organization) and Palmer ([who is never mentioned in media after the game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse)), they've lost their base of operations and most of their military forces and resources, and people are grateful to the planet for saving them from Meteor, so they refuse to use mako anymore. While Rufus still has the Turks by his side and has wealth and influence of his own, the Shinra Electric Power Company is pretty much gone.
[Villain Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainProtagonist): Their employees are the protagonists of *Before Crisis* and *Crisis Core*.

[Adaptational Attractiveness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalAttractiveness): He's quite slender and is quite handsome, especially in the [remake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVIIRemake).
[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): He's quite polite and well-spoken for a villain.

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): How he survived is left up to the "On The Way To A Smile" novellas to explain. He attempts to tell Cloud directly in *Advent Children*, but an annoyed Cloud cuts him off and tells him he doesn't care.

[Antagonistic Offspring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntagonisticOffspring): Not only does he lack any grief when his dad gets murdered, being more glad to have the president title for himself if anything. But *Before Crisis* has him  (SPOILER) secretly give information and funding to AVALANCE  with the end goal of getting his dad assassinated, meaning he's been wanting him dead for years.

[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): A somewhat selfish version. After *VII* he wants to help rebuild the world, but atlhough partially to rebuild Shinra however his speech to Kadaj and On the Way to Smile indicates he sees himslef as responsible and wants to prevent further calamity with his Turks sharing the same belief. *Dirge of Cerberus* implies he's backing Reeve and the World Regenesis Organization to help rebuild the planet. The fact that Rufus is backing the Organization anonymously hints that he isn't as selfish as he seems.
[Badass in a Nice Suit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassInANiceSuit): He's always seen wearing his iconic white suit.

[Badass in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassInDistress): Gets kidnapped/held hostage a lot. Twice in the side story *On the Way to a Smile* and then is held (for a given value of hostage) by Kadaj in *Advent Children.* He's even been held as a hostage by the Turks in *Before Crisis*.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): His artwork implies he wears one under the jacket of his suit. His *Compilation* redesigns retcon it to just a normal suit.

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): In a world where Materia offers powerful spells, people use weapons as long as their own bodies and military soldiers can be upgraded by getting implanted with foreign cells, Rufus's weapon of choice is... a shotgun.

[Bastardly Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BastardlySpeech): His introduction, where he states that his plans are to turn the Planet into a police state. Thankfully, he never gets the chance to go through with it.
[Bastard Understudy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BastardUnderstudy): To his father; he's content being the vice-president for now and is loyal as such, but is scheming to make his own plays for power.

[Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe): He gives a grandiose speech about how he's going to rule the world through fear moments after Sephiroth has murdered every last person in his building. Rufus' ambitions have to be put on hold since the world being destroyed is not in his business plans, and once Sephiroth is stopped being a villain just isn't pragmatic for him anyway.
[The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): In *Advent Children*. He manages to spend a great deal of time manipulating Kadaj and his brothers, and possibly Cloud as well.

[Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive): Let's put it this way: His dad didn't want him taking over the company because [Rufus was even more corrupt than he was](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilerThanThou). As his page quote demonstrates, he thinks his father's practice to manipulate public opinion to make people like Shinra is too wasteful; he finds fear will do the job just as well.

[Damsel out of Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselOutOfDistress): Despite being kidnapped a few times, he never really seems that concerned about it and can generally [Xanatos Speed Chess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/XanatosSpeedChess) himself into a better situation. If not, the Turks find him eventually.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker) His response to the party telling him who they are:
QUOTE  ‘’What a crew.’’

[Dragon Ascendant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonAscendant): He's second only to his father in Shinra's hierarchy. After Sephiroth kills the President, Rufus quickly moves to become the company's new head.

[Dual Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss): The one time he's fought, he has his pet Dark Nation casting protective spells on him; both are pushovers (Rufus has the least amount of HP of any major boss enemy.)

[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): Played with. Cloud stays behind alone to fight him one-on-one, but Rufus' dog Dark Nation accompanies him into battle. However, Dark Nation dies easily, so it does boil down to just Cloud vs Rufus.

[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): When Cloud fights Rufus on the balcony of the Shinra President's office, he has Dark Nation at his side; Dark Nation is a weaker enemy that casts protective spells.

[Handicapped Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandicappedBadass): Spent *Advent Children* in a wheelchair for most of the movie. It's  (SPOILER)  partially to hide what the Remnants are after but also  because he'd become infected with Geostigma as well as recovering from a broken heel and broken ribs from *On the Way to a Smile.*

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): He toys with it in the first game but remains a firm heel. It takes being blown up by Diamond Weapon to make him do it right. Come *Advent Children* Rufus seems to have had a slight change of heart, coming to accept the lifestream a cycle of life and death as one of the truths of the planet. He even gives the big bad a speech on how humanity as a collective whole himself included will always rise up to stop catastrophes such as Jenova and Sephiroth whenever they appear.

[I Control My Minions Through...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IControlMyMinionsThrough): As he freely admits, he'd much rather control the world through fear rather than through money like his father did.
QUOTE **Rufus**: I'll control the world with fear. It takes too much to do it like my old man. A little fear will control the minds of the common people. There's no reason to waste money on them.
[Man of Wealth and Taste](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManOfWealthAndTaste): He's an antagonist and wears an immaculate white suit at all times with well-groomed hair to boot.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Rufus means 'red haired,' referencing both the red logo of Shinra Corp and that in the original game Rufus's hair tended towards reddish-blonde.

[Nice to the Waiter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceToTheWaiter): He actually seems quite respectful to Shinra's rank and file employees. When the cargo ship docks in Costa Del Sol and the local staff are preparing the helicopter for Rufus's departure, Heidegger yells at the dockworkers to throw his weight around while Rufus merely compliments them on their effort. It's implied that he's respectful to competent employees, since if Cloud does badly in the Junon sendoff he'll threaten funding cuts while if Cloud does well he'll congratulate and reward the troops. He constantly berates Heidegger for the latter's screw-ups, which he's never shown doing to any other Shinra executive.

[Nominal Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NominalHero): He's a good guy post-*VII*, but only insomuch that he helps the heroes because the destruction of the world is something he's not keen on letting happen. In the meantime he's still shifty and untrustworthy, and  (SPOILER) sat back and let Kadaj summon Bahamut SIN to attack Edge while the item Kadaj is looking for in the city is sitting in his lap.

[No One Could Survive That!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoOneCouldSurviveThat): His apparent demise in *VII* — his office is bombarded by energy blasts from [Diamond Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination) and blown up. Rude and Reno speculate that because his body *isn't* found in the office that he actually might've survived the attack.

[Obfuscating Disability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObfuscatingDisability): In *Advent Children*, he spends most of the movie in a wheelchair and covered in a blanket since he's contracted severe Geostigma.  (SPOILER) While the Geostigma part is real, it's not as severe as he pretends, and he stands up with no issue later in the movie to taunt Kadaj with Jenova's remains.

[Overshadowed by Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OvershadowedByAwesome): In any other game, Rufus' intellect and vast resources would make him a very formidable antagonist. Unfortunately his competition is [Sephiroth,](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhysicalGod) putting him firmly in [Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe) territory.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): He actually gets on very well with the Turks and in *On the Way to a Smile,* goes out of his way to both help and attempt to save some fellow patients while he is captive.
    - He allows the party to escape with them when Sephiroth seals off the crater rather than leave them at his mercy. While he doubles back and arrests Tifa and Barret for execution for both their crimes as Avalanche and to scapegoat them for Meteor, Rufus seemingly allows the rest of the party, who were not officially part of Avalanche and are either former Shira employees (Cid, Cait Sith and Vincent) or citizens of other nations (Red XIII and Yuffie) to walk away unharmed.
[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): He's still not a good person and his goal is to keep Shinra on top, but he also recognizes you have to have a livable world to do so.

[Pretender Diss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PretenderDiss): Delivers one to Kadaj  (SPOILER)  by pointing out that the real Sephiroth would have easily sensed that he had kept Jenova's remains close. 
QUOTE **Kadaj**:  (SPOILER)  Mother?!  
**Rufus**: A *good* son would have known.

[Punch-Clock Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunchClockVillain): Rufus doesn't hold grudges or act on things like petty revenge. Everything he does is what he considers good for business. Even Barrett had (short-lived) praise for his courage at defending the towns and populations from the Weapons.

[Rank Scales with Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RankScalesWithAsskicking): Defied, he's fought as a boss shortly after you first meet him but isn't that tough and has no real power. After that, he never takes part in battle again.

[Reassigned to Antarctica](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReassignedToAntarctica): He is put on an "extended assignment overseas" at Junon (in actuality, put under house arrest in Junon) after it became apparent that  (SPOILER) he aided AVALANCHE in their efforts to eliminate Shinra so as to remove his father from power . Considering the alternatives (ie, being sacked and/or executed), this punishment was actually very light.
[Sawed-Off Shotgun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SawedOffShotgun): His weapon in *VII* and *Advent Children*.

[Sequel Reset](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequelReset): In the original game, Rufus gets [seemingly vaporized](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoBodyLeftBehind) by the Diamond Weapon after he attempts to break through the barrier that Sephiroth has walled himself behind. For all intents and purposes, the story treats the scene as him being [Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal). It wasn't until years later in *Advent Children* that it is revealed that Rufus miraculously survived.
[Sharp-Dressed Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SharpDressedMan): His white business suit and jacket.

[The Sociopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSociopath): Set up as one in the original game, feeling little empathy and wanting to control people using fear to keep them in line. The expanded universe considerably tones it down.

[The Starscream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStarscream): He had been plotting to take control of the company long before his father died at Sephiroth's hands—he was secretly the chief financier of the original incarnation of Avalanche and their [inside man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole) in the company, caring not for Avalanche's goals but only for the instability they would bring. When his involvement was uncovered by the Turks, he was merely placed on an extended house arrest as punishment.

[There Is Another](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThereIsAnother): According to extended materials, he has at least  (SPOILER) two illegitimate half-brothers. The older one, Lazard Deusericus, is the director of SOLDIER in *Crisis Core*. The Shinra infantryman outside Lazard's office mentions that he reminds him of the VP. The younger one, Evan Townshend, is the focus of the side-story, *The Kids Are All Right.* Rufus notes that Evan looks much more like their father than he does.

[Troll](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Troll): To Kadaj in *Advent Children*.  (SPOILER) He spends the entire film feigning like he has no idea what Kadaj is doing and who he is, when he knows exactly what's going on. He further keeps the box with Jenova's remains concealed under his cloak the entire film knowing it's what Kadaj is looking for, and when he stands up and casts the cloak off to reveal the box he takes a moment to let Kadaj realize what it is before taunting him and tossing it over the side of a building.  When Rufus says "I've never had this much fun", he's being serious; this is all a big joke to him.

[Tyrant Takes the Helm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TyrantTakesTheHelm): The original President Shinra was no saint by any means, but the minute Rufus takes over, he vows to AVALANCHE in a [New Era Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NewEraSpeech) that he's going to be even worse; whereas his father controlled the world with money and manipulating public opinion to make people like Shinra, Rufus decides that controlling people through fear is a much better option. Although  (SPOILER)  President Shinra destroyed an entire sector of his city, killing untold numbers, just to wipe out a terrorist hideout, whereas Rufus 'died' defending the same city from WEAPON and then resurfaced alive and repentant, if still manipulative, in *Advent Children*.
[The Ugly Guy's Hot Son](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUglyGuysHotDaughter): Rufus is much easier on the eyes than his fat, middle aged father.

[The Unfettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered): Nobody has ever seen him cry and he is never shown to have much fear for his own safety, much less those of his subordinates or anyone else. Case of Shinra shows his [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) as a calculated method of patiently getting back on top of the world and rebuilding the corporation (which he had done, by the time of *Advent Children*) after Mako ceased to be a viable power source. [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) laughs about his scene in *Advent Children*, "Only someone like Rufus, a big shot president, would be able to jump off a building without hesitation and expect his Turks to take care of everything".

[The Unreveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnreveal): When he and Cloud meet in *Advent Children*, Rufus begins to explain how he escaped his office before Diamond Weapon killed him but Cloud doesn't care and interrupts him before he finishes. The side novellas later explain it.

[Villain: Exit, Stage Left](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainExitStageLeft): After you do enough damage to Rufus in the boss fight with him, he grabs his chopper and flies off, allowing him to continue antagonizing AVALANCHE for the rest of Discs One and Two.
[Villain in a White Suit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainInAWhiteSuit): His white suit represents his power, influence, and morally unscrupulous nature.

[Worf Had the Flu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorfHadTheFlu): In *On The Way To A Smile*, he spent most of his episode being badly injured after narrowly surviving getting vaporized by Diamond Weapon and thus made him an easy target of kidnapping and assassinations.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): Is murdered by Sephiroth to the despair of no one. Even his own son Rufus, who appears on the scene shortly after the fact, cares more about taking his father's place than his actual death, and no one else in Shinra seems to miss him either.

[Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): Implied in Denzel's segment in the OVA *On the Way to a Smile*, since Denzel's parents, both of whom worked in Shinra, were killed when he dropped Sector 7 onto the Slums.

tropeName: But for Me, It Was Tuesday
tropeNotes: [But for Me, It Was Tuesday](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButForMeItWasTuesday): Cloud is rather annoyed Shinra doesn't recognize him, as he points out he's overseen the graduation of every SOLDIER member and excluding heroes like Sephiroth he can't be bothered to remember every one of them.  (SPOILER)  This is foreshadowing to how Cloud was never a member of SOLDIER to begin with.
[Cigar Chomper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CigarChomper): Is frequently shown smoking a cigar.

[Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive): He's constantly using military force and media manipulation to control people and lead Shinra to domination of the world.

[Create Your Own Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreateYourOwnHero): The entire playable party owes their main motivations to be being abused by President Shinra and his company. An example of this is Barret who was once an advocate for Mako energy and Shinra, but they soon burned down his hometown as revenge for an explosion that the town had nothing to do with. This event sets up Barret to become a staunch anti-Shinra extremist, and all the other party members have their origins tied in someway to Shinra and their activities.
[Dirty Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldMan): He can be found in the Honeybee Inn dressed up like a king and doing some roleplay with one of the girls working there.
[Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): Positioned as the original game's [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) until Sephiroth's Masamune finds its way through his back.

[The Emperor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmperor): Officially he is the owner and CEO of a conglomerate, but make no mistake, in practice, he is this. Wields absolute, unchecked power? Check. Is the boss of a superpower? Check. Is in control of large amounts of the planet? Check. Has expansionist and conquest policies? Check. Commands vast armies? Check. Controls politics? Check. Can hand it all off to his kid? Check.

[Even Evil Has Loved Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasLovedOnes): Has a couple of [Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog) moments directed towards Rufus, hinting that he genuinely loves his son, if only in his own way.

[Every Man Has His Price](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryManHasHisPrice): According to Rufus, he tried to rule the world with money, pouring billions into creating the best weapons and soldiers, or just outright bribing or buying out potential threats to himself or his interests.
[Fat Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatBastard): He's portly and very unpleasant.
[Faux Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FauxAffablyEvil): He feigns politeness while obviously talking down to the members of AVALANCHE.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): Judging by the scene at the Honeybee Inn, besides being a [Dirty Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldMan), President Shinra also talks about the Promised Land as a sort of birthright, like his family passed its legend on for generations as their long-term goal. While we never see how he compares himself to the Cetra amidst his plans to seize Aerith for being his guide there, this does mean he strongly seems to believe every single horrific action he takes is perfectly justifiable in his plans for Neo-Midgar, because he thinks he was *born* to seize the Promised Land. He also makes a side comment that someone matching Sephiroth's description is *not* the one that will lead them there, inclining an immensely bitter sense of betrayal over Sephiroth's "disappearance".

[His Name Really Is "Barkeep"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HisNameReallyIsBarkeep): In the [Japanese version](http://forums.qhimm.com/index.php?topic=11867.225), at least, his first name is actually President (his title is "head of Shin-ra Company", not president; President is his *name*). Obviously this joke couldn't be translated into English, so the English version just gave him President for a title and made him [Last-Name Basis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastNameBasis).

[Impaled with Extreme Prejudice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice): Finds himself on the receiving end of this at the end of the player's opening stay in Midgar; once Cloud recognizes the sword used and left behind, Sephiroth firmly takes over as Big Bad for the rest of the game.

[I Was Quite a Looker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWasQuiteALooker): Implied to be good looking (or at least powerful enough to be attractive) when he was younger. Enough at least to have landed an attractive wife and at least two mistresses.

[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): To the citizens of Midgar. Drop part of upper Midgar onto the Sector 7 slums, blame it on AVALANCHE terrorists, and then send in Shinra to clean up and help the survivors. He always preferred to take the route that would get him what he wanted *and* would make Shinra look good to the general public.

[Non-Action Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionBigBad): [Positioned as the main antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss) until Sephiroth makes his presence known and becomes [The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought), and even then he's clearly a [Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy) who prefers to have his [Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mooks) do the dirty work for him.

[One Nation Under Copyright](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneNationUnderCopyright): Midgar was built and financed with Shinra resources, and their monopoly of the Mako the city needs to run makes him the ruler in all but name.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): Despite their strained relationship, he also seems to have a soft spot for Rufus according to *Before Crisis* (where Rufus is put under house arrest rather than being fired or killed for  (SPOILER)  helping AVALANCHE take him down ) and *On the Way to a Smile* (where the presidential passcode of Shinra's HQ turns out to be Rufus' birthdate).

[President Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PresidentEvil): In practice, he's the real ruler of Midgar. You meet the actual Mayor in *VII*, and he readily admits to this. The mayor of Midgar is essentially a [figurehead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuppetKing) hostage cooped up inside the Shinra building.

[Really Gets Around](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallyGetsAround): To date, he has three named children all sired by three different women, though two are illegitimate and he only regards Rufus as his possible successor.
[Starter Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StarterVillain): He's the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) up until the *real* [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) puts a sword in his back.

[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): Sephiroth kills him after he meets AVALANCHE personally a mere two times; he's one of only three present Shinra executives, the others being Turk Tseng and Reeve, to not have a boss fight attached to him.

[Villain with Good Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainWithGoodPublicity): He aspires to this, but it gets zigzagged. It seems those living below the plate know better, and those above the plate fall for it because they don't realize how awful conditions in the slums are, or don't think Shinra is at fault.
[Wicked Cultured](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WickedCultured): Listens to classical music while watching Sector 7's plate collapse and kill off most of the inhabitants of the sector.

[Annoying Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnnoyingLaugh): At least Rufus thinks so.
QUOTE [Stop that stupid horse laugh.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging)

[Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): He takes his anger out on his employees in a very physical manner. He's so abusive that it takes Cid about 5 minutes to convince the Highwind crew to mutiny and work for him instead.
[Beard of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeardOfEvil): A rather rugged one.

[Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe): He tries to be the main threat to AVALANCHE after Rufus’s supposed death, but like Rufus, he’s out of Sephiroth’s league as an intimidating threat to the heroes.
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): Was this to President Shinra, before Sephiroth showed up and caused Rufus to take over. Afterward he serves as this to Rufus.

[Dragon Ascendant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonAscendant):  (SPOILER) He and Scarlet briefly become the heads of Shinra after Diamond Weapon seemingly kills Rufus. It doesn't last long, as AVALANCHE destroys their [Humongous Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumongousMecha) a few real-life hours of gameplay later.
[Evil Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilLaugh): A rather [annoying one](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnnoyingLaugh), as his colleagues (mostly Rufus) frequently tell him.
[Fat Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatBastard): He's very large and very cruel.

[Humiliation Conga](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumiliationConga): The party's first visit to Junon is one of these for him. He can't find Sephiroth when the latter kills several soldiers, Rufus is forced to take a cargo ship to the western continent because Heidegger doesn't have any of Shinra's airships ready, Rufus repeatedly insults his [Annoying Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnnoyingLaugh), he fails to keep Cloud's party and Sephiroth from stowing away on the cargo ship and Rufus viciously berates him for his screwups. It ends with [Heidegger angrily throwing everyone around him into the sea.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown) Notably, several of the Junon soldiers commented on how edgy and irritated he was during Rufus's visit.
[Ironic Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IronicName): He is named after a German philosopher warning against technology, environmental destruction, bioengineering and many other things Shinra does.

[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): He's the head of the Public Safety division, yet as the de facto head of Shinra's infantry and SOLDIER, his department causes rampant death and destruction (presumably this is meant to invoke the more euphemistic names that government departments under dictatorships have, such as [The Ministry of Truth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/NineteenEightyFour)).

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Despite the real Martin Heidegger's philosophical views, he was also a supporter of [Those Wacky Nazis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThoseWackyNazis). That makes his name suitable for a militaristic asshole like the video game Heidegger.

[Nervous Wreck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NervousWreck): He becomes this once Rufus becomes President, as it's implied he's scared for his job because Rufus is angry at his performance. Several of the Shinra soldiers in Junon [Lampshade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Lampshade) how edgy and irritated he is because of several of his screw-ups, such as his inability to find Sephiroth and not having any of Shinra's airships ready for Rufus's travel.

[Never My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMyFault): Towards the end of the game around when he and Scarlet become the heads of the Shinra corporation, Heidegger vents his frustration by citing everything that went wrong for him was Avalanche's fault. He wasn't even above reassigning blame to cover his own fatass in Before Crisis, wherein he became head of the Turks as well as the public safety committee of the company.

[Out-of-Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutOfCharacterMoment): Despite his normally buffoonish nature, during the Sapphire Weapon's attack on Junon, Heidegger performs his duties with unwonted cool professionalism.

[You Are in Command Now](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreInCommandNow): Spin-offs establish he took over SOLDIER when Director Lazard went AWOL. *Before Crisis* toys with the idea of him taking over the Turks as Veld's leadership comes into question, but ultimately it's Tseng to takes the reins.  (SPOILER) He also takes control of Shinra period when Rufus seemingly dies towards the end of Disc 2 of the original game, forcing the team to fight him and Scarlet in their Proud Clod mech just prior to Hojo.

[A-Team Firing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ATeamFiring): Lampshades it when her guards open fire on Barret and Dyne and can't hit anything. Scarlet mocks their poor aim, then knocks one of them off a cliff and takes his gun to show them how it's done. She honestly doesn't do much better.

[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): She has a special-designed gas chamber designed for executions in Junon, that in her own paraphrased words is designed to be as painful and deadly as it can possibly be, and she gets a kick out of the idea of using it on Tifa and Barret just because she could. If that isn't crazy, it'd be hard to tell what is at that point.

[Dark Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkActionGirl): A [Downplayed Trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope) in that she isn't that much of a physical or magical fighter and she can’t pilot a mech without Heidegger’s help, but put her in a giant mech and she *will* make heads roll.

[Designated Girl Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesignatedGirlFight): During the attempted execution of AVALANCHE on Disc 2, she suddenly hates Tifa, referring to her as stuck-up and pursuing her when she flees, leading to a minigame where the two have a slapfight.

[Evil Is Petty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsPetty): When ordered to head Tifa's execution, she sends her to a gas chamber designed to be slow and painful, and when Barret and Cait Sith move to try to save her by leaving to find a different solution, Scarlet locks the door behind them solely so no one can help her — even giving chase after a miraculous escape *just to drag her back to her death.* There's being a [Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator), but there's also her flaunting and having an [Evil Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilLaugh) about it in their faces, meaning she's reveling in getting to be as petty as humanly possible.

[Lack of Empathy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LackOfEmpathy): She rejoices in murdering AVALANCHE on live television via gas chamber, and takes a moment to slap Tifa and insult her while she's trapped in the chamber.
[Lady in Red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyInRed): Her dress betrays her nature as a dangerous and violent woman.

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): The low-resolution model reduces the titillation factor, but her dress is cut very low at the front, and is slit to mid-thigh at the side. The remake delivers her in far higher resolution, however, allowing her assets to be displayed a lot better.
[Noblewoman's Laugh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoblewomansLaugh): Similarly to her business associate, Scarlet has an obnoxiously high pitched cackle of a stereotypical evil female aristocrat.
[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): Shinra's lone female executive.

[You Are in Command Now](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreInCommandNow):  (SPOILER) She and Heidegger seize Shinra towards the end of the game, and this forces the player to fight them in their giant mech only a few steps away from the second disc's final fight.

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): Sure, he's just as greedy as his peers, and doesn't blink at the destruction of Sector 7, but he's surprisingly friendly with the party when he doesn't recognize them, and doesn't get involved with Shinra's more vile actions. Overall, he doesn't seem that much worse than [Reeve](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate).
[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): He seems to be this for Shinra; he gets no respect at all from anyone. Not that he deserves it.

[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): He was the least important of the Shinra executives in the original game and is the only one not to appear in any other *Compilation* titles. This also means it's entirely unknown what happened to him after the original game; he's still alive out there somewhere but no one even mentions him.
[Disney Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyDeath): Apparently being hit by a truck was not enough to actually kill him.

[Fat Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatBastard): The man likes *lard* in his tea. The "Bastard" part is downplayed in the sense that, while he's working for an evil company, [he himself isn't very evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HarmlessVillain).

[Fat Idiot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatIdiot): He's so pathetic that he's left alive by the end of the game; not even worth killing. He's the only Shinra executive to survive, other than  (SPOILER) Reeve, who turned good, and Rufus, who got caught in a massive explosion and was thought to have died.

[Fire, Ice, Lightning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIceLightning): During his boss fight, he can shoot Cloud's party with a gun that fire specialized bullets, which are the equivalent of a tier 2 fire, ice, and lightning spell.

[Harmless Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HarmlessVillain): Palmer is a joke and everyone knows it. He's ironically the only Shinra executive who fights you without a mech or monsters backing him up, and all he has is a weak mako gun which fires nerfed tier 2 elemental spells.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): Bizarrely, the one time Palmer is actually given a task he's actually *very good at it*. While Cid's rocket has been rusting and leaning for three years, he gets it fixed in record time to launch at Meteor. When it's launched, he makes sure to lock the Auto-Pilot device to ensure it won't be diverted from its path.
[Hot-Blooded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotBlooded): He's *extremely* hyper, to the point where his idle combat pose looks like he's *tap dancing*.

[The Load](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLoad): Hasn't been the head of an actual department for two decades and is routinely insulted and ignored during board meetings, and yet is still a part of the Shinra board of directors.
[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): He managed to survive being hit by a truck.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): You know how he narrowly managed to avoid being chopped to bits by the Tiny Bronco after the party's fight against him? Well, aside from the aftermath, that was taken word for word from the demise of that German Mechanic that Indiana Jones was fighting in *[Raiders of the Lost Ark](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/RaidersOfTheLostArk)*.
[Stupid Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StupidEvil): [Played for Laughs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayedForLaughs), he's comical and harmless and barely even qualifies as "evil" for how inept he is.

tropeName: This Looks Like a Job for Aquaman
tropeNotes: [This Looks Like a Job for Aquaman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisLooksLikeAJobForAquaman): After the Shinra Space Program is reduced to a budgetary footnote for 20 years after the failure of the Shinra No. 26 rocket, Palmer gets his moment to shine during the Meteor Crisis when Rufus orders him to [Break Out the Museum Piece](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakOutTheMuseumPiece) and repurpose No. 26 into a ballistic missile to destroy Meteor with. It still fails.

[Villain: Exit, Stage Left](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainExitStageLeft): Palmer **attempts** this when you bottom out his HP and he nearly gets sliced and diced by the Tiny Bronco's rudders, but a Shinra truck amusingly runs into him on his way out and bumps him off the screen. He gets better, seeing as he's seen again on Disc Two.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): We don't hear anything about his whereabouts after the failure of Rufus' plan to hit the Meteor with the Shinra No. 26 rocket. By the end of the game, he's probably still alive somewhere.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): He's the only Shinra executive with a sense of morals or righteousness. The only truly villainous thing he does is kidnap Marlene to use as leverage so AVALANCHE will let Cait Sith tag along after being outed as [The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole); considering what we know of Reeve already and looking at his role in the expanded universe though, she was really in no danger at all.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): Late into *VII* and into the *Compilation*, he's trying to make up for the harm he did to the world helping to build Shinra's power base.

[Becoming the Mask](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BecomingTheMask): Sort of. He was already sympathetic to the heroes' cause, but didn't trust AVALANCHE at first. He didn't so much change personality-wise, but instead came to the realization that AVALANCHE was operating on the same wavelength he was.
[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): After *VII*, Reeve is the head of the World Regenesis Organization that's rebuilding the planet after Meteorfall.
[The Dividual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDividual): As the pilot of Caith Sith, Reeve is technically the character too.

[Evil Cannot Comprehend Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCannotComprehendGood): The reason he changes his mission from spying on AVALANCHE to helping them. Reeve can't understand why anyone would go through so much trouble to help people or fight Shinra if there isn't something in it for them. When he finally starts to figure it out, he runs into [Good Feels Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodFeelsGood).

[Good Feels Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodFeelsGood): The final impetus for his [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn). After being given a taste of being a hero, Reeve liked it much better than being a corporate pawn.
[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): After playing as a triple agent between AVALANCHE and Shinra for much of the game, he eventually settles on AVALANCHE.

[Honest Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonestCorporateExecutive): From what we see of him he was competent and effective at his job. He's the only Shinra executive besides Rufus's old man that is not a boss in this game (Heidegger and Scarlet operate the Proud Clod boss encountered near the end of Disc 2, and the others are all fought on foot.)

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Reeve is of Middle English origin and means "bailiff". The medieval reeve of a castle or landholding was an administrator for the king or someone of high position, befitting Reeve's position as one of Shinra's executives. Also, whether coincidentally or not, his name is furthermore homophonous with the Scandinavian verb "riv", meaning "scratch", possibly alluding to the fact that he's the man behind Cait Sith.
[Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy): He prefers to operate things behind the scenes and send Cait Sith in to do field operations.
[Only Sane Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneMan): He's this for Shinra's board of directors, being the only one who isn't a megalomaniac and/or an idiot.

[Out-of-Character Alert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutOfCharacterAlert): Reeve messes up at the late game of *VII* when he starts talking with his Cait Sith methods in a panic within the same room as Heidigger and Scarlet while the Sister Ray is being prepped by Hojo. Showing his cards too blatantly has them call him out on it, and he admits he's called Cloud's party to stop Hojo — causing the pair, now lacking a leader with Rufus' seeming death and taking control for themselves, to throw him into house arrest as a traitor while they completely ignore Reeve's warnings about the [imminent dangers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfExplodium) of firing the cannon again.

[Redemption Earns Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEarnsLife): The only Shinra executive to repent (as well as the only one besides President Shinra that the player does not engage in a boss fight), and the only good one among them in the first place, is the only one to survive the events of *VII*.
[Tall, Dark, and Handsome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TallDarkAndHandsome): Makes the cut at 5'11, has black hair, is Olive skinned, and designed to have the "ruggedly handsome" look.

[Technopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Technopath): It appears that Reeve can somehow control Cait Sith with his mind while the machine has some kind of AI personality that controls what he isn't focused on. That or his subconscious fills in the rest for him. How he accomplishes this, whether through technology, materia, or some genetic trait is never fully explained.
[Token Good Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate): Among Shinra's executives. Even before he defected to AVALANCHE he was pretty much the only one of them with a conscience.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Reeve is the one who designed the Mako Reactors and the Mako refining process. If he had never made his discovery then Shinra wouldn't have risen to power, probably wouldn't have found Jenova, and the many world-ending events the planet experiences over the next two decades wouldn't have happened.

[Abusive Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusiveDad): He injected Jenova cells into his own son and took him away at birth without letting his mother even hold him. Furthermore, Sephiroth was raised without knowing that Hojo was his father, but he does admit that [the man is "a walking mess of complexes".](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards)

[Always Someone Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSomeoneBetter): Gast Faremis is this to him. When Sephiroth first realizes what Hojo's experiments are, he says that they'll never put him on the same level as Gast. Vincent also says outright that Hojo has "so little scientific talent, especially compared to Professor Gast."

[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy): He is ultimately one for Vincent Valentine. Hojo stole the woman he loved, impregnated her, experimented on their child to create  (SPOILER)  Sephiroth  and then shot Vincent himself to experiment on him as well.

[Barred from the Afterlife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarredFromTheAfterlife): The novel *The Girl Who Travels the Planet* reveals that, due to his experiments and his lack of humanity, his soul can never enter the Lifestream.

[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): He's the main antagonist of  (SPOILER) *[Dirge of Cerberus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DirgeOfCerberus)*, commanding the Tsviets through the body of Weiss.
[Big "NO!"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigNo): When his digitized spirit is destroyed by Weiss and Nero merging.

[Body Horror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyHorror):  (SPOILER) His Helletic Hojo form is a disgusting mass of writhing flesh that wouldn't look out of place in *[Resident Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/ResidentEvil)*.
[Boss Corridor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossCorridor): The final meeting with Hojo has a long catwalk between the top of the Sister Ray and the control panel where Hojo can be found.
[Brain Uploading](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainUploading): You encounter a copy of his mind in  (SPOILER) *Dirge of Cerberus*.

[Climax Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClimaxBoss): When you confront him on the cannon at the end of Disc Two, you discover that  (SPOILER) he's Sephiroth's father, and therefore is directly responsible for nearly all the hardship the Planet had to endure.  He's immediately fought in a three-phase fight, with the last phase possessing some quick and deadly combo attacks.

[Contrasting Sequel Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContrastingSequelAntagonist): If Sephiroth is a [foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) for [Kefka](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI), then Hojo is one for the scientist who "created" Kefka: Cid Del Norte Marguez. Like Cid, Hojo is a [Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist) employed by [The Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmpire) for their nefarious purposes who played a significant role in creating the [Psycho Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoPrototype) [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad). However, whereas Cid eventually [realizes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization) the horror of what he's done and decides to [leave the Empire as a result](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefectorFromDecadence), Hojo consistently has zero remorse or concerns for the nature of his experiments, and in fact continues them *not* because they directly benefit Shinra (though that is a fortunate coincidence for him) but because of his completely amoral [scientific curiosity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience).

[Create Your Own Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreateYourOwnHero): His experiments on both Cloud and Vincent are ultimately the main reason they're both heroic badasses (though the former was still able to throw Sephiroth into the Lifestream and the latter was a Turk *prior* to being experimented on, there's no doubt they owe many of their abilities to the experiments).

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): He is particularly snarky with Cloud whenever they meet. In *Crisis Core* he gets very sarcastic when discussing Hollander, snapping to Genesis "a second-rate hack like Hollander couldn't cure a cold."

[Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): Thanks to his role in everything bad that happens to the planet, he becomes the final Shinra executive AVALANCHE has to fight in the original game <sup>note </sup>   Not the final Shinra employee period; Sephiroth is an EX-SOLDIER and is the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) of the game, and therefore the final Shinra employee past and present fought in the game  , at the end of the return to Midgar, which ends the second disc. This also makes Hojo the last boss encountered prior to Shinra's collapse and the player being able to access the game's [Very Definitely Final Dungeon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VeryDefinitelyFinalDungeon), once they are prompted to switch to Disc 3.

[Drunk on the Dark Side](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrunkOnTheDarkSide): The more his theories are proven right, the more unhinged and fanatical Hojo becomes. It reaches a breaking point when the team has to confront him in a 3-stage boss fight to close out the second disc of play, and he mutates himself as the boss encounter progresses.

[Evil Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGenius): He may be a monster, but Hojo *is* very intelligent and perceptive. However, even he admits he's not as smart as he likes to think when it becomes apparent he's underestimated Cloud and Sephiroth.

[Evilutionary Biologist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilutionaryBiologist): He believes humanity is mostly useless except for a few promising specimens, and is obsessed with the potential of science to advance society.

[Fate Worse than Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FateWorseThanDeath):  (SPOILER)  Hojo loses control over Omega and he’s erased from existence after Weiss and Nero merged together into one and Weiss enters Omega .

[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): The first stage of the boss fight with Hojo has him assisted by two "samples" of two enemies encountered in the Sunken Gelnika. Do not bother killing them because he'll revive them; they die when he moves on to Phase 2.

[For Science!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience): He just wants to do science for the sake of science. When Cloud calls him out on this towards the end of the game, Hojo admits outright his only desire is to see his path in life vindicated by proving he was right.

[Four Eyes, Zero Soul](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourEyesZeroSoul): He's one of only two characters in the original game to wear glasses, and is one of the most downright evil characters in the setting.

[Godhood Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodhoodSeeker): *Dirge of Cerberus* reveals/retcons that he  (SPOILER) injected Jenova cells into himself in *VII* to try and make his body strong enough to be a vessel for Omega, and his plan in *Dirge of Cerberus* is to use Weiss' body for the same. His goal is to become a cosmic being who will travel the stars, but unfortunately for him, he fails as Nero merges with Weiss and they enter Omega destroying Hojo for good.
[Grand Theft Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrandTheftMe): He takes over the body of  (SPOILER) Weiss the Immaculate prior to *Dirge of Cerberus*.
[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): Hojo has been responsible for almost every bad thing that has happened in the compilation either directly or indirectly.
[Guinea Pig Family](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuineaPigFamily): He used both his wife and son as experiments with Jenova.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): Sephiroth has done thousands of terrible things, including killing Cloud's mother and burning his village down, but we can't really hate him because he's an awesome villain whose origins can be traced back to Hojo himself. Hojo, on the other side of the spectrum, never approaches anything resembling sympathetic or understandable. He is an arrogant misanthrope who can barely be bothered to acknowledge the existence of others unless he has a use for them and he sees everyone as test subjects to be used for his experiments, including his lover and his son. Even his biggest point of pride—his scientific genius—is undercut by the existence of Gast, who is shown and stated to have been far smarter than him while lacking even a hint of his cruelty. At no point will players feel anything for Hojo but contempt.
    - As alluded to in *Final Fantasy VII* but greatly expanded upon In *Crisis Core*, (SPOILER) despite the fact that Zack literally saves his life from Genesis and Hollander, Hojo [later repays him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBastard) by capturing both him and Cloud to be experimented on after they're both wounded from fighting Sephiroth. When Zack breaks himself and Cloud out, they're both branded fugitives. In other words, it's ultimately because of Hojo and his insane [desire to experiment on Zack and Cloud](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithSyringes) that the entirety of Shinra betrays them, ultimately resulting in Zack's death .

[Hazy-Feel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HazyFeelTurn): Played with in *Before Crisis*, he plays with the idea of leaving Shinra to join AVALANCHE, but changes his mind. His initial reason is that he's impressed with Fuhito's experiments, but later decides they aren't good enough to be worth leaving Shinra's facilities to work on.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): When confronted by Genesis, who spouts off yet another verse from LOVELESS, Hojo doesn't just finish it, but knows the verse *exactly* before referring to it as an ancient epic. Albeit he also dismisses it as drivel immediately afterwards. He also has a strange habit of [attracting women through no effort of his own](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllGirlsWantBadBoys), and is heavily implied to be the leader of Sephiroth's fan club and knows some rather, uh, *odd things* about him.

[Humans Are the Real Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumansAreTheRealMonsters): In a series full of monstrosities that Cloud and the rest of the party fight, Hojo stands out as the only human being who sees people as a means to an end than individuals that he can experiment on and is proven to be even more monstrous than Sephiroth.

["It" Is Dehumanizing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItIsDehumanizing): Hojo rarely uses names when speaking to people, usually referring to them as "subjects" or "specimens". He comments in *Crisis Core* that unless they prove exceptional enough to warrant the effort, he doesn't care to learn the names of those he experiments on.

[Kavorka Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KavorkaMan): He somehow attracts women to him despite looking unremarkable and acting repulsively. In Costa del Sol he's inexplicably surrounded by women on the beach, and we later find out that he more or less stole Lucrecia away from Vincent.

[Labcoat of Science and Medicine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LabcoatOfScienceAndMedicine): Wears one constantly. Even when relaxing on the beach in Costa del Sol, trying to get a tan(!) he keeps the lab coat on.

[Lack of Empathy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LackOfEmpathy): Hojo cares about nothing and no one except for how they can benefit his experiments. Even  (SPOILER) his son  was just another test subject to him.

[Laughing Mad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaughingMad): He is fairly restrained in the original game, until you confront him at the end of Disc 2, during which he falls into hysterical laughter. In *Dirge of Cerberus*, however, he takes it up a notch.

[Like Father, Like Son](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LikeFatherLikeSon): *Dirge of Cerberus* reveals that he and his son had the same end goal in mind  (SPOILER) — merging with an [Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination) and absorbing the Planet's Lifestream to become a god —  and even go about accomplishing it in similar ways.

[Luke, I Am Your Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LukeIAmYourFather): Near the end of the first game, he reveals  (SPOILER) he is Sephiroth's father, something even Sephiroth himself doesn't know.  He gets a kick out of the idea that  (SPOILER) Sephiroth treated him poorly and looked down on him, unaware Hojo was his father.

[Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist): One of the most famous examples in video games, he is completely amoral and lives to do science no matter the consequence. It really sets the tone for his character when his first scene has him attempting to breed Aerith and Red XIII, rationalizing it as saving two endangered species from extinction and referring to the pair as specimens.
[Maker of Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakerOfMonsters): His experiments resulted in many monsters that the player fights in the game.

[The Man Behind the Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMonsters): Aside from Genesis, all of the antagonists of the *FF7* universe can be traced back to his experiments on Jenova. And even then, it could easily be argued Genesis never would have become evil if Hojo hadn't shown up Hollander with his own experiments.

[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): He was able to convince Lucrecia Crescent to marry him, carry their child and use their child for the Jenova Project, by the time Lucrecia realized what kind of man Hojo was, it was already too late.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Not him, but his first [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) form:  (SPOILER) "Helletic Hojo" is a mistranslation of "Heretic Hojo", which fits his abominable experiments quite well.

[Misanthrope Supreme](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MisanthropeSupreme): Hojo has nothing but disdain towards his fellow human beings, seeing them as inefficient and weak. The few he doesn't dismiss or try to kill end up as his experiments. *Dirge Of Cerebrus* establishes that  (SPOILER)  he's become so weary of everyone that he wants to abandon the planet to destruction and make a new one with Omega's power .

[Omnicidal Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnicidalManiac): Two of the experiments he was involved in nearly resulted in the end of the world, and it is heavily implied that the planet's destruction was exactly what he was hoping for, to prove the superiority of science over nature.

[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): When the party finally fights him at the end of the first game's second disc, they discover he's  (SPOILER) injected Jenova cells into himself , causing him to mutate as the fight wears on.
[Only One Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyOneName): He's only ever called "Hojo". Given that Hojo could be a given or family name in Japanese, we can't even say which it is.
[Parental Neglect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalNeglect): Has little or no concern for his own son after he used him like a tool.

[Professor Guinea Pig](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProfessorGuineaPig):  (SPOILER)  Eventually injects himself with Jenova cells. Admittedly, he didn't do this as part of a test run; it was only after he proved it was (relatively) safe by injecting it into his wife and son.

[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss): When AVALANCHE has to fight him towards the end of the original game, he starts off as a normal dude, but then mutates into a Jenova copy with a trident arm, and then a featureless floating creature, all over three separate phases of the same boss fight.

[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): He’s an arrogant mad scientist who sees other humans as weak unless he sees them as beneficial for his experiments.  (SPOILER) In *Dirge Of Cerberus*, he possesses Weiss the leader of Deepground, and plan to use Omega to absorb the lifestream and then travel to space, making him think he is invincible, but after he kills Nero, he was so self absorbed in his plans he failed to realize that Nero entered Weiss’s body, making him lose control of both Omega and Weiss, and is erased after Weiss enters Omega .

[The Starscream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStarscream): Since Hojo is the one who created Sephiroth, he tries to help  (SPOILER) his son  with his goals as opposed to the other Shinra board members who are trying to stop Sephiroth from destroying the planet.

[Teeth-Clenched Teamwork](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeethClenchedTeamwork): He has this dynamic with the rest of Shinra. Everyone in the company is fully aware of how amoral and creepy Hojo is and wants as little to do with him as they can get away with, and he is perfectly fine with this because he feels the same way towards them, wanting to be left alone to his experiments unless he needs something from one of them.

[Villains Out Shopping](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainsOutShopping): The group can run into him chilling on the beach in Costa Del Sol.
QUOTE  **Cloud**: What are you doing...? 
**Hojo**: It should be obvious. I'm getting a tan.

[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown): By the time the party faces him, he's completely lost what sanity he had (thanks in part to the Jenova cells invading his body), and raves that he's an idiot for not realizing the full potential of his experiments and writing them off. *Dirge of Cerberus* takes it even further.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): After an entire game of calling Cloud [moronic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouFool), Hojo quickly goes back on it, perhaps showing he has some respect for Cloud's stubbornness (so similar to his own). "Actually, you might be cut out to be a scientist."

[You Killed My Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyFather): He killed Professor Gast, Aerith's father. He also places Aerith and her mother into seven years' worth of inhumane experiments, which eventually resulted in her mother's death while escaping Shinra.
[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): Collectively they seem a decent bunch to hang out with, unless you're their target.

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): The playable Turks in *Before Crisis* were just named after the weapons they wield, but the *Last Order* OVA gave most of them names in the production notes.
    - Rod (Male) is Alvis. - Gun (Female) is Emma, who is also the older sister of Elena. - Two Guns (Male) is Ruluf. - Shotgun (Female) is Freyra. - Martial Arts (Male) is Maur. - Martial Arts (Female) is Juget. - Katana (Male) is Balto. - Legend (Male), Nunchaku (Male), and Knife (Female) however remain unnamed. Shuriken (Female) would be named Cissnei in *Crisis Core*.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): The remaining Turks become this as of *Advent Children*.

[Badass in a Nice Suit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassInANiceSuit): The iconic Turk uniform is a dark blue/black suit that they all wear. There's a partial exception in Reno, who wears his messily with his jacket unbuttoned and shirt untucked.
[Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk): Rude and the two "Martial Arts" Turks fight hand-to-hand.
[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Shotgun sees anything from patrol missions or anything outside of participating in dangerous missions as tedious time killing.

[Boss Corridor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossCorridor): The last meeting with the Turks is in Midgar's train tunnels; the player must travel a little bit away from the screen in the first part of the tunnel before the Turks run up behind them.
[A Day in the Limelight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ADayInTheLimelight): *Before Crisis* has the Turks take the center stage, showing them as once a larger organization.
[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): In *Advent Children*, Rude and Reno are clearly out of their league against Kadaj's gang. They don't care. They *just keep fighting*.

[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): Collectively the entire group is this trope to Rufus, acting as his personal enforcers. *Before Crisis* establishes backstory that while the Turks are part of the larger Shinra hierarchy, their final loyalty is to Rufus.

[Dual Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss): Two encounters against Reno & Rude can be started in Gongaga and then in a sunken Gelnika ship. Neither of these fights are too tough, and the second one has a bugged Rude who will not attack at all after making a move. Once one is defeated, you have a limited amount of time to take out the other one before he runs off.
[Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine): In Wutai, they agree to a truce with Cloud's party after Corneo kidnaps Yuffie and Elena.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing):  (SPOILER)  The fact that none of the Turks recognize Cloud despite his proclamation of being an ex-Soldier First Class is one of the early signs that his claims may not actually be true.

[Four Is Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourIsDeath): Played straight in the first game, where they're something of a legitimate threat ([until Sephiroth shows up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilerThanThou), at least). Subverted in the film, given their [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn).

[Friendly Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlyEnemy): Something that Reno [acknowledges](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging) in their final encounter in the original game. Their last battle is even *optional* to boot; you can just choose not to fight them and they back off.

[Goldfish Poop Gang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldfishPoopGang): Reno and Rude quickly devolve into this in the original game, showing up repeatedly to get their butts handed to them and then running off. They only become dangerous again in their last battle when accompanied by ([previously thought to be incompetent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoHarmlessVillain)) Elena.
[Great White Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreatWhiteHunter): Shotgun descended from a wealthy family of Hunters from Mideel. Yes, she hunted monsters before she joined the Turks.
[Guns Akimbo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunsAkimbo): Two Guns from Before Crisis dual wielded two pistols.
[The Gunslinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGunslinger): Tseng and Gun (Female) fight with handguns.

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): The remaining Turks complete this by *Advent Children*, helping Cloud and the others in their fight against Kadaj, Loz, and Yazoo. However, *Before Crisis* shows they started their turn by helping civilians evacuate during Meteorfall, with Reno, Rude, Elena and Tseng evacuating separate Sectors before reuniting with the remaining Turks to complete their rescue efforts.

[Hello, [Insert Name Here]](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HelloInsertNameHere): The *Before Crisis* Turks all have names assigned by the player and have no canon names. The exception is "Shuriken (Female)", who was [named](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamedInTheSequel) Cissnei for her *Crisis Core* role. It is also noted that Cissnei isn't her real name.
[Hero of Another Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroOfAnotherStory): *Before Crisis* serves to reveal the Turks saved the world from a threat never before spoken of — Zirconiade.

[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): The official Romanizations [in Japan] of Elena's and Reno's names were, once upon a time, "Yrena" and "Leno" [specifically in the *Official Establishment File* artbook].

[I Owe You My Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IOweYouMyLife): *Before Crisis* reveals that after Veld and the player Turks betrayed the company and went rogue, Scarlet ordered the last three members loyal to Shinra — Tseng, Reno and Rude — exterminated and the Turks shut down. Rufus intervened to keep the group alive, demanding their absolute loyalty to him in exchange.
[Katanas Are Just Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KatanasAreJustBetter): Katana (Male) fights with katana.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): [The iconic Turk theme](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jSAjNWypykQ) accompanies them in all their appearances.

[A Million Is a Statistic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AMillionIsAStatistic): The effect of Reno and the Turks following through with the command to drop the Sector 7 plate, killing thousands of people, has noticeably less impact on the characters (and the fans) than Sephiroth impaling Aerith.

[Private Military Contractors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrivateMilitaryContractors): As revealed in *Before Crisis*, many if not all of the members of the Turks consist of reputable warriors, mercenaries, criminals, and Shinra-raised soldiers recruited from various backgrounds by the Shinra corporation to serve as fighters to protect its interests.

[Punch Clock Villains](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunchClockVillain): To the point that they even agree to help the heroes when they are found off-duty in Wutai. They'll still commit atrocities when ordered to by their boss.

[Put on a Bus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PutOnABus): The *Before Crisis* Turks including former commander Veld all leave the company and go their separate ways after the game's end. The group returns for a brief cameo in *On The Way to a Smile*, with Veld getting a supporting role, but otherwise they've not been heard from again.

[Quirky Mini Boss Squad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuirkyMiniBossSquad): At their worst, they are comic relief, usually too silly to be a real threat, and all wear the same uniform. At their best, they are a genuinely threatening organization responsible for espionage, assassinations and mass-murder (especially the last time you fight them in the original game, which can be a difficult fight depending on how you play it).

[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): When you play the original *Final Fantasy VII*, AVALANCHE has to engage a few members of the Turks sans Tseng at least twice through the game. The first instance is with Reno in the opening stages when you see him for the second time at the Sector 7 pillar, and the other required fight is with Rude in Rocket Town on Disc 2. You can skip out on the Reno/Rude duels by staying out of the areas where you run into them, and doing a lengthy sidequest allows AVALANCHE to turn down a final encounter at the end of Disc 2 (otherwise, you have to deal with all the Turk members outside of Tseng in Midgar in a 3-on-3 boss fight, and unlike the other fights, this one can be frustrating and painful, especially if you try to steal equipment they have).

[Reformed Criminal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReformedCriminal): Two Guns was formerly a bodyguard of Don Corneo. Rod was formerly in a bike gang and tried to steal a bike from the Shinra headquarters garage which led him to being caught, but Veld offered him a position in the Turks.

[Resignations Not Accepted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ResignationsNotAccepted): Due to the nature of their job they're privy to quite a few company secrets, so any Turk that resigns is considered a security risk.

[Screw This, I'm Outta Here](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere): If you're given the option of refusing the final fight with them in Midgar and take said option, Reno and Rude won't push it, noting Shinra is ancient history. They'll say their goodbyes, turn around, and leave.
[Shotguns Are Just Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShotgunsAreJustBetter): Shotgun (Female) fights with shotguns.

[Skippable Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkippableBoss): The only times they have to be fought is the first Reno fight and the fight with Rude at Rocket Town. All others can be skipped or those areas passed over. Even the final confrontation is skippable if you've completed the Wutai quest.
[Throw Down the Bomblet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowDownTheBomblet): Elena and the Legendary Turk fight with thrown explosives.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): It was the player character in *Before Crisis* who requested the investigation of the Nibelheim reactor thus summoned Sephiroth to his birthplace.

[Villain: Exit, Stage Left](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainExitStageLeft): In all of the Turk fights except for the Rude battle in Rocket Town, the Turk(s) you are fighting will turn tail and run off once you deplete their health bar; in the Reno/Rude fights, you then have a limited time to deplete the other's health before he leaves on his own and deny you his drop item, and in the 3-on-3 battle towards the end of the game, once one Turk runs out of life, they all run away. This is also when they pull the plug on doing Shinra's dirty work; If you decline to fight them, they no longer care and leave on their own.

[Wolfpack Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WolfpackBoss): The last fight with the Turks the player has the ability to play is a 3-vs-3 fight in Midgar at the end of Disc 2 and towards the end of the game. This fight brings out recurring bosses Reno and Rude plus Elena, and unlike the other Turk fights, this one has a decent to tough challenge to it since the Turks fight as a team, they now sport 5-digit health bars each, Elena can use Confusion, and each Turk can now absorb a specific element and be healed by it. If the player did the Wutai side-quest, they'll be given the option of skipping this boss fight altogether, though the Turks do have strong items to steal if the player elects to go forward with the boss fight.
[Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes): He and Elena show up in time to save Rufus from falling to his death in *Advent Children*.

[Characterization Marches On](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterizationMarchesOn): His appearance at the attack on Sector 7's plate had him laugh at the coming destruction and slap Aerith in the face mercilessly, both at odds with his depictions in the Compilation (where he's shown as professional but not cruel). The latter was at least addressed in the Compilation by a novella, but the first remains unaddressed.

[Childhood Friend Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildhoodFriendRomance): For Aerith, sort of. They were never friends and he's older than her by several years, but he was one of the few people Aerith knew when she was a child, and he's had an unrequited thing for her all the time since.

[Dub-Induced Plot Hole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubInducedPlotHole): The North American version of the game treats the aftermath of his ill-fated encounter with Sephiroth in the Temple of the Ancients as being fatal. In the original Japanese version, he survives but is laid up recovering for the rest of the game, hence why he doesn't show up in Discs 2 and 3. This caused some natural confusion for members of the North American audience when he returns with the rest of the Turks in *Advent Children*.

[Expository Hairstyle Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExpositoryHairstyleChange): Has his hair up in a ponytail in *Before Crisis* but lets it down after taking on the leader role of the Turks at the end of the story.
[The Gunslinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGunslinger): While he doesn't show it off in the original game, appearances in the *Compilation* give him handguns as his preferred weapon.
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Other media has spelled his name as Zheng or Zeng, the latter being an alternate way of spelling Tseng.
[Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease): With Elena. Rude and Reno directly state she likes him, and he later asks her to dinner, but nothing is known to come of it.
