[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): At no point does the party ever actually engage Tseng, the leader of the Turks, in combat. He can, however, be fought in the Training Mode in *Before Crisis*.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): He and Rude become this in *Advent Children*, and Rude suggests this is true for the rest of the surviving Turks as well.

[Characterization Marches On](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterizationMarchesOn): Reno was a competent [Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker) in the original game. In *Advent Children*, he became the [Plucky Comic Relief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PluckyComicRelief). There have been reports, though, that the [Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker) version of him was an alteration of the translation and that he was supposed to have been comical in the original Japanese. According to [this](http://forums.qhimm.com/index.php?topic=19279.0), Reno's personality in the JP version of FF7 was in the middle between the localization (which lost much of his charm) and the Compilation (which played up his silliness). He was playful and laidback but still took his job seriously (with his career as a Turk being just a job as far as he cares).
[Character Tic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterTic): Sticking his tongue out, particularly in installments after the original game.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Reno is very sarcastic and snarky.
[Evil Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilRedhead): Reno, but only in the original game. In other appearances, he's more an [Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain) than straight evil.
[Fiery Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FieryRedhead): Reno could be considered a male example, being very spry and talkative.

[Hair Color Dissonance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairColorDissonance): His [official artwork](https://imgur.com/a/sgGPdUU), [in-game battle model](https://imgur.com/a/nEy011A), and media beyond the original game depict him with having bright red hair while his [overworld model](https://imgur.com/a/PwkXCGP) gives him a less saturated color more similar to brown.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): Reno never suffers the consequences for setting off the bomb which destroyed Sector 7 (an act similar to burning down a house to kill one mosquito). Hell, Barret never even remarks about this whenever he meets Reno in person.

[A Sinister Clue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ASinisterClue): Much like Sephiroth, Reno is left-handed, since that's the hand he holds his stun baton in (he also wears a watch on his right hand.) In-game this is a *literal* clue as you can Steal the Tough Ring accessory from him, last seen in flashback equipped by...Sephiroth.

[All Love Is Unrequited](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllLoveIsUnrequited): He has a crush on Tifa, who is both unaware and uninterested. Hilariously if you have Tifa in your party while fighting the Turks, Rude tries to avoid attacking her.

[Ambiguously Brown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBrown): Rude, though described by [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) as somewhat resembling a person of South American descent rather than African descent.

[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): Like Reno, Rude becomes this is *Advent Children*. However, this detail is only made clear in the Complete version of the film where the two talk about the Turks' previous role as the "obliterators" of the world and how they have a lot they need to atone for while they're still alive.
[Bald of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaldOfEvil): Rude hasn't got a hair on his head.
[Barefisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarefistedMonk): He beats you up with his bare hands.

[Boss-Altering Consequence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossAlteringConsequence): If you have Tifa in your party, he will try to avoid fighting her if he can, and if she's the only one standing, his attacks will miss more frequently.

[Cool Shades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolShades): Rude is always shown with his sunglasses. In *Advent Children* we briefly see his eyes when they fall off and Reno steps on them; after a look of horror from Rude, he stands up and [pulls a spare pair from his pocket](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnlikelySpare).
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): The fight with Rude in Rocket Town has him standing behind two Attack Squad soldiers.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): When Rude is fought in Rocket Town and Midgar, he can use an electric attack called Grand Spark.

[Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes): She and Tseng show up in time to save Rufus from falling to his death in *Advent Children*. Later in the film in the *Advent Children Complete* version, she then saves Rude and Reno from a helicopter crash alongside Tseng.
[Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress): Elena gets kidnapped by Don Corneo along with Yuffie in the Wutai sidequest after going off on her own to search for him.

[Dark Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkActionGirl): Elena seems to be the least competent member of the Turks. [However, in the one battle in which you fight her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoHarmlessVillain), she turns out to have more HP than Reno or Rude (said HP can't be scanned), is able to defend herself rather well and can inflict Confusion on your characters.
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Elena's name is actually written as Irina in katakana.

[Laser-Guided Karma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedKarma): She blames Cloud for Tseng's supposed death, and tries to punch him in Icicle Inn. If Cloud (easily) avoids her pathetic attack, she'll slip and go *falling down a hill out of town*.

tropeName: Minion with an F in Evil
tropeNotes: [Minion with an F in Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MinionWithAnFInEvil): Elena is... spectacularly bad at her job sometimes. Her career highlights include blabbing sensitive intel to the enemy instead of just [Evil Gloating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGloating), getting kidnapped by a Z-grade crime boss, (probably) missing a punch so badly she ends up falling down a hill and (potentially) just walking away from a climactic clash with the heroes because she's just not feeling it. Even if she manages to punch Cloud unconscious in Icicle Inn, her immediate response is feeling regretful about it and just leaving him behind to recover rather than apprehending him.

[More Deadly Than the Male](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreDeadlyThanTheMale): Despite her bumbling newbie track record at eveything else, in battle she absolutely clowns both Rude and Reno in terms of strength and competence.

[New Meat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NewMeat): With the Turks being bled down to just Tseng, Rude, and Reno after *Before Crisis*, Elena is recruited early in *Final Fantasy VII* to bolster their numbers. And boy does it show.

[Only Sane Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneMan): While the original game leans heavily into her being a bumbling new recruit, she's still significantly smarter and more mature than Rude and Reno generally are
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): The one time Elena is fought, she can use a fire attack on the team.

[Sibling Rivalry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SiblingRivalry): *Before Crisis* reveals that Elena's older sister was a Turk, and Elena resented her for outperforming her; she refused to join the Turks while her sister was a member. She joined after her sister retired along with many other Turks from that game, following their defeat of Zirconiade and decision to follow Veld's lead.

[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): Elena is the female of the four. Averted with the *Compilation* establishing there were more female Turks in the past, her sister being one of them.
[Throw Down the Bomblet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowDownTheBomblet): Her weapon is thrown explosives..

[All Love Is Unrequited](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllLoveIsUnrequited): It's implied that she falls for Zack sometime during the story. Shortly after she met him, however, Zack fell from Mako Reactor 5 to meet Aerith, who he formed an instant connection with and started dating shortly after.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): "Shuriken (Female)" was just one of several generic Turks the player could choose to play as in *Before Crisis*. *Crisis Core* gave Cissnei an actual name and a prominent story role.

[Canon Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonName): Averted. Cissnei straight up tells Zack that "Cissnei" is *not* her real name. Meaning whatever the player named her in *Before Crisis* is just as valid as her *Crisis Core* codename.
[Fangirl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Fangirl): It's heavily implied in ''Crisis Core Final Fantasy VII Reunion" that she started and runs his online fan club.
[Fuuma Shuriken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FuumaShuriken): Cissnei fights with an oversized red shuriken.

[Improbable Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableAge): Zack notes she's very young, even by Turk standards. She explains this is due to her being raised inside the company to be a Turk since she was very little.

[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): She defies orders to retrieve Zack and Cloud on the shores near the Nibel Plains, thinking she's helping rescue them from Shinra. Quite the contrary, the Turks were trying to rescue the two of them from the Shinra Army as well, and her letting them go ultimately resulted in Zack meeting said Army face to face.

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): In *Crisis Core* where her suit is form-fitting, she's often flirtatious with Zack and she gets a gratuitous [beach scenes at Costa Del Sol](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeachEpisode) showing off her well-toned stomach in a bathing suit.

[The Paranoiac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParanoiac): Apparently Cissnei, or otherwise known as Shuriken in Before Crisis, thought everyone was after her due to being raised in the Turks from childhood. Her training encouraged this mindset and it took her colleagues helping her to abandon it.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): She looks the other way so Zack can escape being a test subject with Cloud (the latter of whom is visibly suffering from severe Mako addiction), lies to Tseng to give them a better chance of getting away, and even gives him the keys to a motorcycle (complete with sidecar, so Cloud won't be at risk of falling off in his catatonic state).
[Tyke Bomb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TykeBomb): She was an orphan who was "adopted" by the Turks so they could raise her to be one of them from an early age, which is why she has no family of her own.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Her ways of trying to help Zack get a head start and escape the Turks are entirely successful. Too bad this also means that when the Turks are eventually looking to find Zack and Cloud to save them instead, [they fail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoneHorriblyRight) — which lets Zack stumble into the horde of Shinra troopers that sealed his fate.
[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): His last name is never given in the game proper, and wasn't revealed until years later in the 10th Anniversary Ultimania.
[Always Someone Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSomeoneBetter): He's this to Hojo; most in Shinra are open in their consideration that as brilliant as Hojo is, he's nothing compared to Gast.
[Disappeared Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearedDad): Aerith's. Gast was murdered by Shinra soldiers under Hojo's command when his daughter was twenty days old.
[For Science!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience): His goal seemed to be a genuine understanding of the Cetra.
[Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist): Edged towards it studying Jenova; when he realized what she was he backed off.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): During the 1930s, there was a german scientist called Professor Herman Wirth, who searched for an ancient civilization and a "mother goddess" on the north pole. Wirth is derived from the German word Wirt, meaning bartender. Gast is a german word meaning guest, but could also refer to a customer of a Wirt/bartender. Wirth and Gast also look very similar.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): Heavily implied by his reaction when Ifalna tells him about how Jenova originally killed almost all the Cetra, especially when he realizes that Shinra extracted her cells to create Sephiroth.

[Screw This, I'm Outta Here](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere): When he found out from Ifalna that Jenova was an [Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination), Gast left Shinra.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): His discovery of Jenova would lead to the creation of SOLDIER, Sephiroth, and Genesis. Though Gast left the company, it was too late to undo his discoveries.
[Abusive Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusiveParents): *Dirge of Cerberus* makes it completely clear that she fully consented to inject Jenova cells into her unborn child.

[All Love Is Unrequited](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllLoveIsUnrequited): Played with. Vincent fell in love with her and she cared for him too, but Lucrecia was guilty of being involved with the experiment that killed his father and pushed herself away from him and into Hojo's arms.

[And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream): She's sealed herself in a cocoon of crystallized Mako out of guilt for her actions, and is unable to die. Whether she can escape or not is unknown, but she doesn't want to as her imprisonment was self-imposed.

[Apologises a Lot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ApologisesALot): In *Dirge of Cerberus*, nearly every flashback Vincent has of her involves her apologizing for something. Considering the things she's done, it's not hard to understand why.

[Bitch in Sheep's Clothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BitchInSheepsClothing): She's soft-spoken, amiable, and [Apologizes a Lot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ApologizesALot)... but she *constantly* hurts Vincent, and she experimented on her own child.

[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker): She wants to die, but thanks to Hojo's experiments cannot. So she decided to do the next "best" thing: creating crystallized Mako to encase herself in within a cave.
[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): After she refused to admit responsibility for her actions, she sealed herself in a mako crystal in a cave.

[Guilt Complex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuiltComplex): She first suffers this when gets Grimoire killed when she researches Chaos, then it got worse when she rejects Vincent's attempt to console her and go for the heartless scumbag Hojo. And when she sees her son's future and is horrified by her actions. When her son is taken away from her without being able to hold him, she immediately thinks that her son is dead. And combining it while dealing with the emotional turmoil about Vincent's death makes it turn suicidal.
[Horrible Judge of Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HorribleJudgeOfCharacter): Everyone who knew Hojo knew he was a scumbag of the highest order, yet Lucrecia was his lover.

tropeName: I Did What I Had to Do
tropeNotes: [I Did What I Had to Do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo): Her justification for  (SPOILER) implanting the Protomateria into  Vincent; it was the only way to save his life.

[It's All My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllMyFault): She has this attitude... and she's right. Her carelessness gets Grimoire Valentine killed, her actions get Vincent killed and experimented on, and she abuses her own child in utero by injecting him with Jenova cells - which kicks off the whole mess from Nibelheim onwards.
[Labcoat of Science and Medicine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LabcoatOfScienceAndMedicine): Her white lab coat for a scientist.

[Late-Arrival Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LateArrivalSpoiler): A major factor in understanding her actions in *Dirge of Cerberus* is that her son is  (SPOILER) Sephiroth . This gives away a reveal from *Final Fantasy VII* that  (SPOILER) Hojo is Sephiroth's father.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Lucrecia (and its Latin counterpart "Lucretia") comes from lucrum, meaning "wealth". Lucretia was a mythical Roman figure who was infamously raped by Sextus Tarquinius. This may have been meant to hint at the nature of Lucrecia's forced participation in the Jenova Project in early game designs (when she was named), or it could be meant to emphasize the perverse nature of Sephiroth's conception.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): She was horrified when a vision showed her what her child with Hojo would become.

[No Accounting for Taste](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoAccountingForTaste): Seriously, *what did she ever see in Hojo*? Flashbacks in *Dirge of Cerberus* show he was always a scumbag who treated Lucrecia as horribly as everyone else he interacts with, including insulting and mocking her to her face and bossing her around as a subordinate. Why she chose to pursue a relationship with him is a total mystery.

[Parental Neglect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalNeglect): Ultimately averted, as she wanted to be a part of Sephiroth's life, but was never allowed to see him. She never even got a chance to hold him when he was born.
[Strong Family Resemblance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrongFamilyResemblance): She has very similar hair and facial features to her son.
[They Called Me Mad!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheyCalledMeMad): A more benign version. Her theories about Omega and Chaos were ridiculed and seen as myths, but it turns she was right.

[Troubled, but Cute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TroubledButCute): She's kind [Nice Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGirl) but have a lot of issues like getting Grimoire aka Vincent's dad killed because of her research about Chaos, injecting Jenova cells into her baby aka  (SPOILER) Sephiroth  when she's pregnant, and putting  (SPOILER) the Protomateria containing Chaos  inside Vincent so he can't die.
[Ugly Guy, Hot Wife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UglyGuyHotWife): Though it's ambiguous if they actually wed, she fits this trope with Hojo; he looks rather unpleasant, Lucrecia is gorgeous.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Thanks to *Dirge of Cerberus*, the "unwitting" part is now debatable, but she basically doomed the planet the second she agreed to have a child with Hojo. On a smaller scale, she's also responsible for most of the misfortune Vincent was forced to suffer in his life either directly or indirectly.
[Who Wants to Live Forever?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhoWantsToLiveForever): Hojo's experiments made her immortal, but having to live with the guilt of what she's done put a damper on the idea.
[Always Someone Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSomeoneBetter): Hojo is this to him.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): Despite being the man that had ultimately created Genesis and Angeal, no one is really sad to see him go once Zack finally puts him down, as he was too petty and twisted for either of his creations to actually *care* in any real way. Considering Hollander instigated Genesis' [Start of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StartOfDarkness) solely for the sake of his revenge rather than for healing Genesis out of altruism, it's not that surprising.
[Beard of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeardOfEvil): Has a full bushy beard with matching mustache and sideburns.

[Best Served Cold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BestServedCold): The official series timeline places the Jenova Project as occurring 20 years before *Crisis Core*. Hollander's been waiting a long time to get back at Hojo for outdoing him
[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): Deadly Breath.

[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): He always flees from danger and is visibly intimidated by Shinra's forces. He only fights Zack near the end of the game because he's cornered, and  (SPOILER) is so degraded that he has no choice but to fight for the one hope he has of saving his own life.

[Evil Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGenius): Though outdone by Hojo in both regards, he's still a brilliant scientist and is absolutely devoid of morals. His one advantage is that he's relatively sane [compared to Hojo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist).

[Evil Is Not a Toy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsNotAToy): His attempts to make Genesis his [Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn) backfire when Genesis gets tired of his failure to produce a cure and attempts to kill him.  (SPOILER) He later does so again off-screen, forcing Hollander to inject himself with Genesis's cells to save his own life, and he experiences the same debilitating health as Genesis does for it.

[Evil Is Petty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsPetty): He convinces Genesis to rebel against Shinra and take a large part of SOLDIER with them, and has Genesis wage war on Shinra by promising him a cure for his genetic degradation. Why? To show up Hojo and SOLDIER and prove his specimens are superior.
[Evil Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep): Compared to Hojo's high-pitched voice, Hollander is deep and gravelly.

[Evil Versus Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilVersusEvil): His rivalry with Hojo can be considered this, as both mad scientists are ultimately unrepentant monsters whose plans cause mass death and destruction. Ultimately, his entire beef with [Shinra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilInc) can be considered this as well, with the caveat that innocent people get caught in the crossfire of his revenge scheme.
[For Science!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience): See [Evil Is Petty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsPetty). He particularly wants to prove *his* science is better than Hojo's.
[Humanoid Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination): He transforms into a more monstrous humanoid form thanks to  (SPOILER) the Genesis cells he's injected himself with.
[Hyperspace Arsenal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HyperspaceArsenal): His "Dimension Missile" cinematic attack has him pull a missile larger than he is out of his satchel and hurl it at Zack.

[I Am Your Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IAmYourFather): Attempted, but defied. Hollander tries to claim himself as Angeal's father in the cutscene shortly before Zack faces Angeal, but Angeal just spits in his face about it. Hollander *is* Angeal's biological parent, but Angeal considered his stepfather to be his real father.
[The Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan): He's the real force behind Genesis's army, and the one who convinced Genesis to go against Shinra.
[The Man Behind the Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMonsters): The Genesis Copies are his work, as are Genesis and Angeal.
[Mook Maker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MookMaker): Can spawn monsters to aid him in battle.
[Only One Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyOneName): As with Hojo, it's hard to even say if it's his first or last name.
[Poisonous Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoisonousPerson): Infects Zack with poison and other status ailments.
[Power Gives You Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerGivesYouWings): He sprouts a small black wing over his shoulder  (SPOILER) when he becomes a Genesis Copy.
[Trademark Favorite Food](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrademarkFavoriteFood): He's a fan of Banora White juice, even wearing a shirt depicting the logo under his lab coat.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Genesis's rebellion against Shinra starts the chain of events that, aside many other things, cause Sephiroth to reconsider his allegiance, and then Genesis appears in Nibelheim to give a Sephiroth a breaking speech that finally pushes him into [Start of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StartOfDarkness). Hollander is the one who pushed Genesis's own [Start of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StartOfDarkness) just to upstage Hojo, resulting in countless tragedies in *[Final Fantasy VII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII)* up to the world being in danger.
[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy): To Zack. Genesis constantly antagonizes him through *Crisis Core* and takes this role as Zack’s answer to Cloud's Sephiroth.
[Author Appeal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorAppeal): He was heavily based on Gackt, a Japanese pop star that Tetsuya Nomura was a fan of at the time.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): He wears a long red coat. One of his fanclubs even calls themselves "Red Leather".

[Beta Test Baddie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BetaTestBaddie): To Sephiroth. Genesis was just one of many people around the world who looked up to Sephiroth and wanted to be just like him. Learning that they were made from separate, competing branches of the Jenova Project, just heightened Genesis' jealousy of and ambition to surpass him.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): His weapon is a massive red rapier, to parallel Sephiroth's Masamune.

[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): For *Crisis Core*.  (SPOILER) [Downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Downplayed) in that Hollander is manipulating him for his own ends and Genesis is more desperate than evil. That said Genesis outlives Hollander and stopping him is the climax of the game.
[Blonde, Brunette, Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlondeBrunetteRedhead): He's the Redhead to Sephiroth's Blonde and Angeal's Brunette.
[Clipped-Wing Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClippedWingAngel): After Genesis Avatar is defeated, Zack must fight Genesis again in human form.

[Cold Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColdHam): He tends to be pretty even-toned and doesn't raise his voice a lot, but he still puts a lot of weight and drama into his sentences, especially if he's quoting LOVELESS.
[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): His rapier is a giant red blade that he can imbue with magic to fight.
[Disney Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyDeath): Genesis fell into a reactor, yet it becomes apparent later on that he survived.
[Easily Forgiven](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasilyForgiven): Zack feels sorry for him and lets him live.

[Everyone Is Jesus in Purgatory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneIsJesusInPurgatory): In-universe, Genesis is obsessed with LOVELESS and has written papers on what it might mean. As his condition and sanity deteriorate and his desperation for a cure intensifies, he starts drawing parallels between the events of *Crisis Core* and LOVELESS, and becomes convinced it is some sort of holy prophecy or legend that he must fulfill.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart):
    - To Zack. His quest to become a hero contrasts with the same quest Genesis Rhapsodos undertakes, but whereas the latter's feelings of entitlement to the moniker of "hero" lead to obsession and downfall, Zack's quest to "become a hero" has less to do with personal glory and more with making the world a better place. Zack's will to become a hero motivated him to think for himself and to be guided by his moral compass and sense of justice, whereas Genesis's obsession with becoming a hero drove him to challenge those he saw as hindrances and a need to prove himself as superior to others. Both joined SOLDIER inspired by stories of the hero First Class Sephiroth, striving to emulate him, and both fall from Shinra's graces after learning of the company's corrupt ways. In an inversion of a typical hero-villain story dynamic, Zack dies whereas Genesis lives. - To Angeal as well. They are both SOLDIERs of Project G, both were inspired by Sephiroth to join SOLDIER and both can create copies of themselves. However Genesis and his copies are associated with black wings, whereas Angeal and his copies are associated with white wings, alluding to angel/fallen angel imagery. Both struggle with the man/monster dynamic, Genesis embracing it as it gives him special powers he can exploit to attain his goals, whereas Angeal begins to loath himself.

[Evil Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilRedhead): A ginger villain who massacres a town (including his adoptive parents), turns those loyal to him into copies of himself, and helps drive Sephiroth over the edge at Nibelheim.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Of Sephiroth, obviously. Genesis was intended to be a [Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) to him in personality and appearance, so he copies many elements of Sephiroth's design while other elements are entirely different. This is probably at least partially intentional in-universe — like many kids, Genesis idolized Sephiroth during the Wutai War and wanted to be just like him, so emulating his wardrobe and giving it his own personal touch may have been a deliberate choice on his part.
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): Of *Crisis Core*. Not counting the scripted [Hopeless Boss Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessBossFight) that follows.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Sephiroth. They're both famous First Class SOLDIERs that go rogue from Shinra and seek divine power. However, Sephiroth does so because he comes to think he's an Ancient and should rule the planet; Genesis is trying to save his own life and is resorting to desperate stretches of reason to find a way. Even their designs play into this; Genesis is short-haired, right-handed, has a wing on his left side, and wields a massive straight-bladed sword that he infuses with magic, while Sephiroth is long-haired, [left-handed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeftHandedMirror), with a wing on the right side, and he wields a katana that he never empowers. Also contrast Genesis' demonic-looking Genesis Avatar form with the angelic Safer Sephiroth, and Genesis' belief that he is a monster with Sephiroth's [Godhood Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodhoodSeeker).
[Freudian Trio](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianTrio): Forms one with Angeal and Sephiroth in *Crisis Core*, as the Id; driven by emotion and personal ambition.

[Graceful Loser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser): Twice during the game:
    - The first is during the flashback when he's fighting Angeal and Sephiroth in a training simulation. Despite his ego driving him to turn the match into a one-on-one with Sephiroth and even punt Angeal away when he tries to stop him from taking things too far, Genesis accepts defeat when Sephiroth lands a clean hit on him. [He even tells them not to worry about his minor injury](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustAFleshWound), which becomes bitterly ironic considering that it kickstarted both his physical, and eventual [mental degradation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SanitySlippage). - The second is when Zack defeats him during the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) battle. Having been forced to accept that the "gift of the Goddess" will not save him, he makes no further attempt to resist Zack, and his final words imply that he considers being reunited with his old friends the real gift and dream come true.

[Green-Eyed Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreenEyedMonster): He's jealous of Sephiroth's status as [The Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAce) (as well as the face of SOLDIER), which drives him to attempt to take him on alone during what was meant to be a light-hearted training session.
QUOTE **Genesis:** After all, your glory should have been mine.
[The Heavy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy): In *Crisis Core*, he's the character that the game's events revolve around.

[Heterosexual Life-Partners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeterosexualLifePartners): Genesis is this with Angeal and Sephiroth before  (SPOILER) [his separation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagonAlwaysRebels) .

[Humanoid Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination): In several ways.
    - As a SOLDIER, he's a normal human that has been injected with Jenova's cells. However they manifest differently in him than in Sephiroth due to the different nature of how they received the cells, which is the major reason for his rebellion against Shinra; Genesis' genes are unstable and when he's injured in a sparring match, his body begins to undergo cellular degradation. This first shows itself when he manifests a black wing, but as the game goes on and his condition worsens, his hair lightens to white, and his skin begins to crack and scar. - The Genesis Copies created by grafting his cells onto humans take on his facial appearance and hair, but they also experience the same degradation he does at an accelerated rate. The result is that while a few of them look identical to Genesis, others look even more monstrous than he does to the point they're barely recognizable as human anymore, such as the [G-Warrior strains](https://finalfantasy.fandom.com/wiki/File:G_Devastator_Artwork.jpg)◊. - As the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) (SPOILER) in his Genesis Avatar form, Genesis transforms into a giant, armored version of himself and wields a variant of his rapier.

[Ink-Suit Actor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InkSuitActor): His appearance is heavily based on his voice actor, Gackt. In *Dirge of Cerberus*, they didn't even bother with the ink suit; Gackt got into costume and performed in front of a green screen to be put into the game's secret ending. Gackt had a hand in the design of his outfit.

[It's All About Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe): He leaves SOLDIER in order to find a cure for his condition. This would be fine, except he murders a bunch of innocent people and subjects others to horrendous experimentation at Hollander's hands. He also pushes Sephiroth further into madness because he's attempting to goad the latter into curing him. Needless to say, his selfish actions do not end well for *anyone*.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): He instigated a war, killed his own parents, basically wiped out his hometown's population, subjected an immense amount of innocent people to Hollander's experments, and his presence helped drive Sephiroth over the edge at Nibelheim. Yet he's the only one of the SOLDIERs who survives the entire ordeal. He was last seen in *Dirge of Cerberus*' secret ending with plans for something else, [but it has yet to be followed up on](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeftHanging).

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): He spends quite a lot of time mocking Angeal and Sephiroth's inner conflicts, turns the SOLDIERs loyal to him into copies, and helps kick off the massacre at Nibelheim by pushing Sephiroth over the edge with a [breaking speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakThemByTalking).

[Laser Blade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserBlade): He can channel magic into his sword, giving it the appearance of a lightsaber. Further, the hand motion he employs to activate this resembles the [Trope namer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Series/MetalHeroes).
[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): He fights with sword combos and magic in equal turn, and powers magic into his sword to strengthen it.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): "Genesis" of course parallels Sephiroth's name in Biblical symbolism, but it also means "birth" or "origin". Combined with the origin of his last name, he is "the original epic poem", referring both to his obsession with LOVELESS, and the idea that in-universe he was the original rebel SOLDIER and committed acts that Sephiroth would later repeat.
    - More literally, while Genesis isn't the cause behind all of major problems in the world of *Final Fantasy VII* (that can be laid on Hojo's hands), he *did* instigate Sephiroth's loss of sanity in Nibelheim, and thus is partially to blame for Sephiroth becoming such a major threat to the planet in *VII* and later works. His name also implies that he was the first SOLDIER to be injected with Jenova cells, which would lead to Sephiroth being the perfection of it. - Lastly, his last name is close to "rhapsody", to mean an enthusiastic expression of one's feelings. While cool-headed about it, Genesis is not shy about expressing how he feels about something.
[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): Empowers himself with the Goddess Materia to transform into Genesis Avatar.

[The Paragon Always Rebels](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagonAlwaysRebels): While not as revered or powerful as Sephiroth, Genesis was still one of Shinra's greatest warriors before he turns on them, and when he defects he takes a large number of other SOLDIER members with him.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): He prefers fire and fire-like attacks, such as Flash, Homing, and Dark Energy.
[Power Degeneration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerDegeneration): The procedure that granted him his powers is also what's going to kill him if he doesn't find a cure.
[Psycho Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoPrototype): He's the original Project G SOLDIER. Finding out about it is what helped drive him to evil.

tropeName: Red and Black and Evil All Over
tropeNotes: [Red and Black and Evil All Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedAndBlackAndEvilAllOver): Wears black pants and a top under his red coat, though he's less evil and more a desperate jerk as the game goes on. This color scheme extends to the Genesis Copies, who variably wear replicas of Genesis' outfit or modified Shinra SOLDIER or infantry uniforms that have been recolored red and black.

[Remember the New Guy?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RememberTheNewGuy): Played with. No other version of the Nibelheim Incident has any mention or appearance by Genesis. However, the way he appears in *Crisis Core* allows him to be there without actually retconning the event's other depictions — he appears when Zack and Sephiroth enter the reactor, and the only version of that specific scene that has been shown across the series is the one where Cloud is in Zack's place, so Genesis's absence could be given a [Hand Wave](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandWave) as one of many inconsistencies in Cloud's memories.
    - From a broader perspective, both Genesis and Angeal were never mentioned in *VII* alongside Sephiroth, despite both being close friends of Sephiroth, having fan clubs, and major roles in a war felt throughout the world.

[Sanity Slippage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SanitySlippage): Undergoes one throughout the game, with his dialogue devolving into cryptic and borderline-incoherent recitations of LOVELESS the more desperate he gets. It takes being directly spurned by the "goddess" he was seeking out for him to (somewhat) come to his senses and accept the futility of his actions.
[Self-Made Orphan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfMadeOrphan): He killed his adoptive parents, though we never find out who his biological parents are.

[Sissy Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SissyVillain): His English voice actor goes down this route, and the [Bishoneny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bishonen) appearance, flamboyant hand gestures and *constant* recital of LOVELESS just add to it.

[Then Let Me Be Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThenLetMeBeEvil): Implied with his statement to Zack that as a monster, he has neither dreams nor honor (admittedly a claim that is later disproven by his desire to regain his pride as a SOLDIER).

[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn):  (SPOILER)  He's one to Hollander who manipulated him into going against his former friends on the pretense that he can cure Genesis' degradation, even though Hollander has no intentions of doing so until Hollander himself suffers from degradation .

tropeName: Used to Be a Sweet Kid
tropeNotes: [Used to Be a Sweet Kid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UsedToBeASweetKid): According to Angeal's mother, he was a nice guy growing up.

[Wicked Pretentious](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WickedPretentious): He's one of the world's leading scholars on LOVELESS and is implied to have published writings about his theories to its meaning. Normally, this may have had him come across as [Wicked Cultured](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WickedCultured), but his tendency to spout [Meaningless Meaningful Words](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaninglessMeaningfulWords) at the drop of a hat turns him into a downplayed version of this trope. It doesn't help that literally *every other named character* familiar with LOVELESS considers it [absolute dreck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StylisticSuck).

[With Friends Like These...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithFriendsLikeThese): On the giving end. He's extremely petty towards Angeal and especially Sephiroth, whether out of not taking their concerns seriously (Angeal) or simple jealousy (Sephiroth). It's pretty telling that Sephiroth tells him he can *rot* after everything he pulls.

[Wound That Will Not Heal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WoundThatWillNotHeal): When Angeal interrupts his duel with Sephiroth, his sword breaks in two and part of the blade strikes Genesis in the shoulder. While Genesis treats it as [Only a Flesh Wound](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyAFleshWound), it ends up not healing and getting worse, kicking off his cellular degradation.

[Animalistic Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalisticAbomination): The Angeal Copies are created by grafting his cells onto monsters; the Ahriman, Sahagin, Griffon, and Guard Hound.  (SPOILER) As Angeal Penance he fuses with one each of these copies, and the result is a centaur-like chimera with Angeal's torso and head on the front and various parts of the copies making up the rest of his body.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): He's not a villain at all, he's just trying to do the right thing and sometimes is on the side of Shinra's enemies. The few times Angeal acts outright antagonistic to Zack is when he's in a [Then Let Me Be Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThenLetMeBeEvil) mood.

[The Artifact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheArtifact): Not Angeal himself, but the Buster Sword in the *Reunion* remake. In the original *[Crisis Core](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/CrisisCoreFinalFantasyVII)*, the sword had a much more decorative and ornate grip and crossguard design inherited from *[Advent Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Anime/AdventChildren)*, befitting its origins as a more decorative weapon that justifies Angeal withholding from using it. In *Reunion* it was changed back to the original *VII* design that *[Final Fantasy VII Remake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVIIRemake)* used, a far more industrial and iron-wrought design that no longer lines up with its own backstory.
[Artistic Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtisticAge): He's 25, but acts much older.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): The original wielder of the Buster Sword.
[Big Brother Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherMentor): To Zack, instilling with him what it means to be a true SOLDIER and why those values are important.
[Blonde, Brunette, Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlondeBrunetteRedhead): He's the Brunette to Sephiroth's Blonde and Genesis's Redhead.

[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): As Angeal Penance, he's a  (SPOILER) bipedal chimera-entity formed from several Angeal Copies, with Angeal's face and chest on the torso.

[Freudian Trio](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianTrio): Forms one with Sephiroth and Genesis in *Crisis Core*, as the Ego; the level-headed mediator between the two. Fully demonstrated in the duel between the two when Angeal has to intervene to stop them from taking it too far.

[Gold and White Are Divine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldAndWhiteAreDivine): The Angeal Copies created from his cells take on a prominently silver, white, and gold color scheme.  (SPOILER) This naturally extends to Angeal Penance as well, a chimera of the copies with Angeal himself.

[Good Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodCounterpart): To Genesis.  (SPOILER) While Genesis rebels against Shinra to heal himself, Angeal does it because he's torn between loyalty to Shinra and loyalty to his oldest and best friend. As well, while they're both experiments of Project G, Angeal is the "perfect" result of Hollander's efforts and has a different set of abilities than Genesis does.
[Good Wings, Evil Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodWingsEvilWings): In contrast to Genesis and Sephiroth's black wings, Angeal's wings are white and pure.

[Heel–Face Revolving Door](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceRevolvingDoor): Being torn between his self-loathing, his loyalty to Shinra, his brotherly affection for both Sephiroth and Genesis, and his desire to protect Zack, which side Angeal is on changes in almost every scene he's in.  (SPOILER) He ultimately opts for [Suicide by Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideByCop) at Zack's hands in order to deal with his inability to resolve his inner turmoil.
[Heterosexual Life-Partners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeterosexualLifePartners): Angeal is this to Genesis and Sephiroth  (SPOILER) [before his death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideByCop) .

[Humanoid Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination): He's a SOLDIER, so he's been infused with Jenova cells and Mako energy to create this.  (SPOILER) As a Project G experiment though he's even more on the "abomination" side than normal SOLDIER members.
[I Cannot Self-Terminate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ICannotSelfTerminate): Pretty much the reason why he  (SPOILER) transformed and fought Zack to the death.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Angeal = Angel. Lampshaded when Zack says his wings are those of an angel, not a monster. Secondly, Hewley: he's hewn in two due to his conflicting loyalties. Thirdly, Angeal Penance, representing  (SPOILER) Angeal's desire to invoke [Death Equals Redemption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathEqualsRedemption) by forcing Zack to kill him and take up his legacy .

[Meaningless Meaningful Words](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaninglessMeaningfulWords): He uses the words "dream" and "honor" a lot. As in pretty much every other sentence. Usually when they're in an improper context. Sephiroth lampshades it when he tells Zack about receiving "one of Angeal's famous lectures".
[Mentor Occupational Hazard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MentorOccupationalHazard): Shockingly, this mentor to Zack and hero of Shinra you've never heard of does not survive the game.

[Mistaken for Murderer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MistakenForMurderer): Zack is horrified when he sees Angeal standing over his own mother's dead body, thinking that his mentor had just committed matricide. It's only later that Angeal reveals that his mother Gillian actually [killed herself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide) since she couldn't bear the guilt of her role in Project G any longer.
[No Cure for Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoCureForEvil): Averted,  (SPOILER) End of Gluttony restores his HP.
[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel):  (SPOILER) He merges with other Angeal Copies  to become Angeal Penance.
[Ornamental Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrnamentalWeapon): The Buster Sword costs so much for his parents to have custom-made for him that he dislikes using it to avoid damaging it.
[The Paragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagon): Along with Sephiroth and Genesis, he's one of Shinra's most famous and respected SOLDIERs, and many aspire to his example.
[The Paragon Always Rebels](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagonAlwaysRebels): And he ends up siding with Genesis.
[Power Gives You Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerGivesYouWings): Just like Genesis and Sephiroth, though he gets two and his are white.
[Rapid-Fire Fisticuffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RapidFireFisticuffs): The DMW attack associated with him, Rush Assault, is a flurry of punches and kicks.
[Real Men Wear Pink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenWearPink): An in-game email from his fan club states that he loves dogs, cooking, and gardening.
[Team Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamDad): To Zack, and most of the SOLDIER.
[Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming): As Angeal Penance, all his special attacks are named after the Seven Deadly Sins.
[What Have I Become?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHaveIBecome): He does not take the revelation of what he really is well.
[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): He's very friendly and polite, but  (SPOILER) he's working with Hollander and Genesis.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): He's  (SPOILER) aiding Hollander and Genesis , but his motivations are much more sympathetic, and he  (SPOILER) eventually realizes the error of his ways and aids Zack.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): Post-time skip.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): Inasmuch as he can be considering the [Grey-and-Gray Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreyAndGrayMorality) of Shinra, but he is the director of SOLDIER and is known and respected among the company's military branch for being a good leader.

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): Realizing that he's  (SPOILER) the bastard son of President Shinra, effectively [abandoned](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalAbandonment) by his father he never knew, and that said father was an absolute *monster* in charge of the company  cements Lazard's actions for the rest of the story  (SPOILER) in supporting Genesis and Hollander to rebel against Shinra, albeit for his own agenda.
[First-Name Basis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FirstNameBasis): His subordinates refer to him as *Director Lazard* and his last name is largely ignored.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil):
    - To Hollander. (SPOILER) They both have been snubbed by Shinra and are using Genesis for revenge, but Lazard undergoes a [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) to help Zack while Hollander continues to aid Genesis. And while Hollander becomes a Genesis Copy, Lazard becomes an Angeal Copy. - Also one to (SPOILER) Rufus Shinra once you find out his full backstory. (SPOILER) While Rufus was born into his power and position, Lazard had to work his way up from the slums, and is a much better person than Rufus.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): He is mortally wounded protecting  (SPOILER) Cloud from Shinra forces while Zack is fighting Genesis beneath Banora.

[Humanoid Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination): He eventually becomes  (SPOILER) an Angeal Copy. By the time he finds Zack at the end of the game, he's fully taken on Angeal's face and hairstyle, save for his hair going white due to his degradation.
[Informed Attribute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAttribute): He's said to have not forgotten his roots and has sympathy for others living in the slums, but it doesn't come into play much.

[Luke, I Am Your Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LukeIAmYourFather): He is  (SPOILER) President Shinra's  illegitimate son with a slum woman. This also makes him  (SPOILER) Rufus's older brother and thus rightful heir to the company if his lineage were to be revealed. His discovery of this is why he helps Hollander and Genesis wage war on the company.
[The Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan): He's the one  (SPOILER) funding Hollander and Genesis.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): "Deusericus" is Latin for "silken god", a potential alternate reading of the kanji for "Shinra".

tropeName: The Mind Is a Plaything of the Body
tropeNotes: [The Mind Is a Plaything of the Body](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMindIsAPlaythingOfTheBody):  (SPOILER) As an Angeal Copy , he wishes to help Zack stop Genesis and save the world. Zack speculates that it's  (SPOILER) Angeal's cells  influencing his mind.

[Offscreen Moment of Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffscreenMomentOfAwesome): While Zack is fighting  (SPOILER) Genesis in the caverns beneath Banora , Lazard sacrifices his life to  (SPOILER) protect Cloud from being captured by Shinra.
[Power Gives You Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerGivesYouWings): He sprouts a pair of white wings  (SPOILER) due to being an Angeal Copy.

[Put on a Bus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PutOnABus): He goes missing sometime between Chapter 6 and Chapter 7,  (SPOILER) presumably because Cissnei tells Zack in Chapter 7 that Shinra was beginning to suspect he was the one funding Hollander and Genesis. He reappears near the end of the game to aid Zack in the final chapter.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): He's polite, friendly and sociable with his subordinates, and recognizes Zack's exceptional performance for a Second Class and decides to call on him more often for future assignments.
[Self-Made Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfMadeMan): He came from a single mother in the slums and has worked his way through Shinra to become one of the most powerful men in the company.
[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): His *true* hand in the game's events is a major reveal.
[The Faceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFaceless): He never takes off his helmet so we have no idea what he looks like beneath it.

[Mauve Shirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MauveShirt): He has enough screentime to be more than just an anonymous SOLDIER, but not enough to really be considered part of the core cast, even within the single title he appears in.
[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): He knows a lot about what goes on in Shinra that he explains to Zack.
[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): To Zack, to the point he says in his last emails after Zack awakens at Nibelheim that he's gonna leave Shinra to find him and help him.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): His final email says he's going to come look for Zack, but we never find out his fate. He gets namedropped in the remake, revealing he was alive during the original game, but it's unknown if the remake is canonical to *Crisis Core*.
[The Faceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFaceless): He also never takes off his helmet so we have no idea what he looks like beneath it.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Kunsel. Both are loyal to Zack, but when push comes to shove, Luxiere is willing to capture Zack to get ahead in SOLDIER (though he claims he might be able to use said influence to help Zack), while Kunsel is willing to risk his career to save Zack.
[Hero-Worshipper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWorshipper): Idolizes Zack, as expressed in his emails.

[Mauve Shirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MauveShirt): He makes exactly one appearance in the flesh, before contacting you through mail to be more than just an anonymous SOLDIER, but he's not even as involved with the story as Kunsel is.
[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): His only appearance involves him delivering an explanation for where Sephiroth is when Zack needs it.

[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): To Zack, less loyal than Kunsel, though he muses that perhaps he could capture Zack to get a promotion and then use that influence to help Zack.
[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): We have no idea what happens to him after this game, and he's not even mentioned in *Remake*.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): His swords are large enough to approach Buster Sword levels.

[Black Comedy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackComedy): Glenn seems to appreciate this form of humor, as after their helicopter crashes on Rhadore Archipelago and he and Lucia struggle to find Matt, he flippantly wonders if Matt was eaten. Lucia has to tell him [Dude, Not Funny!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeNotFunny).

[Dreaming of Things to Come](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DreamingOfThingsToCome): While on the helicopter to Rhadore Archipelago at the opening of the game, he has a dream about his confrontation with Sephiroth eight years later.
[Freudian Trio](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianTrio): Glenn is the Id in the trio of himself, Matt (Superego), and Lucia (Ego). He is the most outgoing and confrontational of them.

[Guys Smash, Girls Shoot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuysSmashGirlsShoot): Glenn is the primary smasher of the group, as all of his main attacks comprise of him getting into close range (with the exception of materia, which they all use). Matt is fairly balanced, but Lucia is exclusively a sniper.

[Line-of-Sight Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LineOfSightName): Out of universe, this is how Testuya Nomura came up with the name for this trio. He was drinking green matcha tea at the time, so "Glenn" came from green.

tropeName: Only in It for the Money
tropeNotes: [Only in It for the Money](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyInItForTheMoney): While it may not be his *only* motivation, as he is an aspiring team leader, he is focused on getting a monetary reward for his job. It is implied to be because he is supporting his grandmother.

[Shoot the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheDog): *Almost* literally. He asks for Lucia's gun to shoot a dog so they could use it as a distraction to get away from some monsters, but instead the dog leads them to safety.
[Smelly Feet Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmellyFeetGag): After the helicopter crash, he threatens to wake Lucia up by taking off his socks, but she hurries to her feet before he can.

[Consummate Professional](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConsummateProfessional): She tends to be focused on the next task at hand, and when Glenn talks about owing Matt money, she discusses how P0 SOLDIERs as a whole are called "[Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag) [Zero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTypeZero)" because they result in zero debt for Shinra if they die or fail their mission. Due to this, they are considered outdated and expendable and this doesn't seem to bother her.
[Freudian Trio](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianTrio): Lucia is the Ego, striking a balance between the impulsive Id Glenn and the thinker Superego Matt.
[Friendly Sniper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlySniper): While she can be a bit no-nonsense at times, she is overall a very friendly person and cares a lot for her teammates.
[Guys Smash, Girls Shoot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuysSmashGirlsShoot): Lucia is exclusively a sniper and long range fighter, while Glenn fights up close and Matt keeps a balance.

[Line-of-Sight Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LineOfSightName): Out of universe, Tetsuya Nomura named her and the other two while he was drinking green matcha tea. She was named for "tea" (in Japanese, her name is *Rutia*).
[Only Sane Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneWoman): Despite Matt having the name "The Professor," it is Lucia who is noted for keeping them out of trouble.

[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): She the only female member of the team. Female SOLDIER members existed in the Compilation before, but only in Deepground, and were highly experimental (it is implied that the standard [Bio-Augmentation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BioAugmentation) procedures used on normal SOLDIER members only work on men). P0 types, however, predate the Jenova Project, they are just highly trained [Badass Normals](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal), so there is a woman among them.
[Affectionate Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffectionateNickname): Glenn calls him "The Professor" for his smarts. Matt keeps telling him not to, but it sticks.
[Freudian Trio](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianTrio): Analytical Matt is the Superego, contrasting with headstrong Id Glenn. Lucia, the Ego, balances the two of them out.
[Line-of-Sight Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LineOfSightName): Out of universe, Tetsuya Nomura was drinking green matcha tea at the time he named the trio, so Matt's name comes from "matcha."
[Multi-Ranged Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiRangedMaster): Matt wields both a pistol and a sword, enabling him to fight at both close and long range.

[Survival Mantra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurvivalMantra): Matt recites the [Fibonacci sequence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fibonacci_sequence) when under stress, and in general he is calmed by patterns and numbers.
[Sword and Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordAndGun): Matt wields both a pistol and a sword, displaying his technical skill with the ability to use both weapons at the same time.

[Absurdly Sharp Blade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbsurdlySharpBlade): His Masamune. Not so much in the original game, but displayed in *Crisis Core*: During his fight with Angeal and Genesis, he ends up tearing apart a giant cannon by slicing it through the barrel.

[The Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAce): He was known as the absolute best of the elite group SOLDIER and admired as a hero. He was actually so good that, according to Cloud, the stories people told about him were understating how strong he was — rather than the other way around as usual.

[Actually a Doombot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActuallyADoombot): The "Sephiroth" the heroes face through most of the game is actually a Jenova construct bearing his appearance, though it was being directly controlled by the real deal. The real one fell down the Nibelheim Reactor in his battle with Cloud, had his remains crystallized in Mako at the Northern Crater and is fought as the final boss.

[Alas, Poor Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlasPoorVillain): While Sephiroth doesn't receive any outright sympathy, quite a few characters hint that his cold exterior is a result [of a deep despair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoMadFromTheRevelation).
[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): You really do need to get into the side materials if you want to fill in the blanks this guy's story has.

[And Then What?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndThenWhat): Until the *Compilation*, it wasn't explicit as to what Sephiroth was actually going to *do* with his godlike power after obtaining it, with interpretations ranging from [Take Over the World](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeOverTheWorld) to [Omnicidal Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnicidalManiac).  (SPOILER) According to *Advent Children*, the ultimate result was the Planet's destruction, it's hinted that he intended to use the Planet as a vessel similar to Jenova, and basically lead him towards a new planet (his "Promised Land") and rule it as a god.

[Animal Motif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotif): Between his slit pupils, his tendency to backstab people both figuratively and literally, the fang-like protrusions from his bangs, and his brutal slaying of a Midgar Zolom, you could say that Sephiroth is a bit of a snake.

[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy):
    - To Cloud. Sephiroth was responsible for destroying Nibelheim and killed Cloud’s mother, making him hate Sephiroth for what he did. In *Advent Children*, when he comes back, it becomes even more personal as Sephiroth plans to cause as much misery for Cloud as he possibly can. QUOTE **Sephiroth:** (to Cloud) Tell me what you cherish most. Give me the pleasure of taking it away. - To Tifa. Sephiroth destroyed her home town, killed her father in cold blood and what he did to Cloud, though Sephiroth could care less of Tifa as he only saw her as being lesser than Cloud.

[Audible Sharpness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AudibleSharpness): In his fight with Cloud in *Advent Children Complete*, his Masamune produces several sounds when he swings it around. Not even Cloud's swords have this property.

[Audience Surrogate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AudienceSurrogate): In a comedic way during *Crisis Core*, for those who don't like Genesis or LOVELESS. After Genesis recites a verse and is impressed Sephiroth knows which act it's from, Sephiroth snarks he can't help but recognize it "after [you've] beaten it into my head".

[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): Don't let the composed, calm exterior fool you; following his descent into villainy, Sephiroth is a vicious mass-murderer who doesn't care who he has to slaughter or how many of them to complete his goals. In fact, directly following his [Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn) during the Nibelheim Incident, killing lots of innocent people in a vengeful rage *was* his goal. After that he developed higher aspirations that also involved killing a lot of people.

[Back from the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BackFromTheDead): Technically speaking, Cloud killed him back in Nibelheim, several years before the start of the original game. His "resurrection" is that Sephiroth can manipulate Jenova's cells from within the Lifestream to create a new body for himself as his own. In *Advent Children* he does this again.

[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): Sephiroth's iconic attire is a long black coat. While most other characters get a change of outfit sometime in the series, Sephiroth's outfit is consistent, only featuring minor changes due to [Art Evolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtEvolution).

[Baritone of Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaritoneOfStrength): Both [Toshiyuki Morikawa](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/ToshiyukiMorikawa) and [George Newbern](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/GeorgeNewbern) make him sound smooth, yet downright menacing at the same time, further cementing his status as an unstoppable force of nature. His voice alone conveys power with superiority all in one, further backing up his immense skill with a sword and immense magical power.

tropeName: Battle in the Center of the Mind
tropeNotes: [Battle in the Center of the Mind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleInTheCenterOfTheMind): After being destroyed in his Safer Sephiroth form, he returned to the Lifestream for a final mental confrontation with Cloud. Sephiroth lost, seemingly vanishing from existence.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): His Masamune is depicted from anywhere between six and twelve feet long. You'd think something that long would be impossible to wield, but he somehow manages.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): Sephiroth is the main antagonist of the original game and *Advent Children*.

[Big Bad Ensemble](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadEnsemble): Both Sephiroth and Shinra Inc share the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) role and they’re both searching for the "[Promised Land](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLifestream)", but Sephiroth is searching for it for far more dangerous reasons and is the larger threat of the two.
[Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes): In *Crisis Core* he arrives out of nowhere and saves Zack from Ifrit.

[Bishōnen Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BishonenLine): His Bizarro Sephiroth form is a mutated mash-up of wings, horns and Sephiroth's face over a deformed body. His Safer Sephiroth form on the other hand is essentially Sephiroth himself with his limbs replaced by wings. The battle afterward restores him to full human form, but is a mental battle and not his actual body. His later appearances in *Advent Children* and (metatextually) *[Kingdom Hearts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/KingdomHearts)* retain a mostly humanoid form, with a single black angel wing to evoke the title of his battle theme.

[Blade Spam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BladeSpam): Spin-offs establish him as so fast he's able to swing faster than the human eye can see, letting him hit you multiple times while you only see him swing once or twice. His Limit Break Octaslash is a quick barrage of eight sword blows, usually only taking two or three seconds to land all eight hits.
[Blonde, Brunette, Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlondeBrunetteRedhead): He's the Blonde to Genesis's Redhead and Angeal's Brunette.

[Bootstrapped Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BootstrappedLeitmotif): His theme in the original game was "Those Chosen By The Planet", while the final two battles with him used "Birth of a God" and "One-Winged Angel". The latter track became an iconic song of the game, the entire series, and a huge fan favorite, so in all subsequent appearances, "One-Winged Angel" has been used as Sephiroth's theme in various remixes.

[Breakout Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakoutVillain): Sephiroth started out as but one in a long line of *Final Fantasy* antagonists, but due to the overwhelming popularity of *FFVII*, he became one of the most popular villains in video game history. His appearance in *[Super Smash Bros. Ultimate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/SuperSmashBrosUltimate)* certainly attests to that.
[Broken Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenAce): He was universally admired in SOLDIER, but his professional calmness hid an emotionally insecure child.

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal): Cloud idolized him during their days with Shinra and dreamed of fighting alongside him in SOLDIER but, after his destruction of Nibelheim and killing of Aerith, he firmly became his [Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy).

[Came Back Strong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CameBackStrong): Post-resurrection in *Advent Children* he's even more powerful than he was at the end of *VII*. Unfortunately for him, so is Cloud. And seeing as how Sephiroth has a tendency to die, he [Can't Catch Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantCatchUp).

[Came Back Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CameBackWrong): A side effect of his resurrection in *Advent Children* due to him focusing entirely on his hatred of Cloud and desire for revenge to avoid becoming one with the Lifestream [at the cost of a hefty chunk of the rest of his personality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Flanderization).

[The Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCameo): A rather odd case: (SPOILER) during the duel between Cloud and Sephiroth at the Edge of Creation in [the remake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVIIRemake), a familiar-looking celestial body can be seen in the distance. [According to the guidebook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) *Material Ultimania*, it is indeed Safer-Sephiroth, or at least some kind of image of him. How he can appear in this timeline despite the deaths of the Arbiters of Fate changing the future is unknown, but Sephiroth's dialogue during the scene imply that, from the Edge of Creation, one can see the other timeline, though Cloud never mentions anything of the sort himself.

[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): One of his attacks as Safer-Sepiroth at the end of the game is the Enemy Skill "Shadow Flare", which is a [Palette Swap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaletteSwap) of the standard Flare from the Contain Materia. ULTIMATE Weapon also uses it, but as a final attack, and the Dragon Zombie enemies that can be encountered shortly before Sephiroth also carry this ability.

[Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment): First in reverse, then forwards. In *Crisis Core* and supplementary material it's implied that while he was aloof, Sephiroth was still benevolent and caring in his own strange ways, and was good friends with Angeal and Genesis. Then the Nibelheim Incident happened, and his mind snapped so hard that he shifted into a malevolent [Omnicidal Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnicidalManiac). The events of the main game then brought forth a manipulator working to achieve that goal, and by the time of *Advent Children*, whether due to being more of a resurrected memory or because he's had time to dwell and re-stabilize his mind after death, he's much more focused and contained, controlling his insanity in favor of being genuinely spiteful thanks to [Motive Decay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MotiveDecay).

[Child Soldiers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildSoldiers): *Final Fantasy VII Ever Crisis* shows Sephiroth fighting in the Wutai War when he was ~16 years old, sporting short hair, a shirt under his coat, and a different sword.  (SPOILER) He was already an unstoppable powerhouse greatly outclassing the other early SOLDIERs—effortlessly crushing a platoon of enemy soldiers with Octaslash before obliterating oncoming reinforcements with Firaga .

[The Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne): He proclaims himself such during his rampage at Nibelheim. His original character theme before *One Winged Angel* took off is actually titled *Those Chosen By The Planet*, reinforcing that Sephiroth's delusions of grandeur and belief he is a true Ancient are the product of greatest hubris, with the world suffering the consequences for it.
[Cold Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColdHam): He always keeps his voice calm and controlled, even when delivering hammy threats such as "On your knees. I want you to beg for forgiveness."
[Colony Drop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonyDrop): His plan is to summon Meteor to impact the planet.
[Color-Coded Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedEyes): His green eyes symbolize his power over Jenova and the Lifestream, and his otherworldly nature.

[Combo Platter Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComboPlatterPowers): His [Super-Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperStrength) is truly the stuff of legends and he is supposedly far stronger than even the most outlandish rumours paint him; post-resurrection he demonstrates [Flight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Flight), [Teleportation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Teleportation), [Voluntary Shapeshifting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoluntaryShapeshifting) (courtesy of Jenova, upon whom he was employing [Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession)) and a degree of [Psychic Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychicPowers), as well as all the usual but high-level magical abilities common in the *FFVII* world. After his *second* resurrection it is cleanly demonstrated that he can unleash the deadly plague Geostigma and can create weaker avatars of himself, and he may have achieved [Complete Immortality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompleteImmortality) of sorts in that he basically refuses to die due to sheer force of will keeping his soul tied to the Planet.

[Complete Immortality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompleteImmortality): Even after his physical body is destroyed, he has the sheer force of will to keep his spirit from passing on, making him impossible to kill off for good.

[Conflict Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConflictKiller): An earlier than usual example in the original game, where he takes over duties as the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) from President Shinra at the end of the Midgar Section. The conflict with Shinra doesn't disappear, but it takes a major back seat for the rest of the game.

[Contrasting Sequel Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContrastingSequelAntagonist): To [Kefka](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI). Both are villains who started out as loyal soldiers in their respective [Evil Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilEmpire)'s armies and want to achieve godhood, yes, but they're as different as night and day. Kefka is an extremely colorful [Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam) who is initially outmatched when he stops to fight the party, but gradually becomes more dangerous as the game progresses and eventually becomes an unstoppable force thanks to his cunning rather than brute force. Sephiroth, on the other hand, wears mostly black, is [The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic) or only mildly smug even when cutting a bloody swatch through his foes, and is a [One-Man Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy) from the get-go. Whereas Kefka was an irredeemably evil psychopath who was pretty much a bastard from the start, Sephiroth is a tragic character whose descent into darkness was the result of being used as a pawn his entire life. To top it off, the final battle against Kefka takes place in the upper atmosphere, while Sephiroth is fought at the core of the earth.

[Cool, but Inefficient](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolButInefficient): In the non-Japanese versions of *Final Fantasy VII*, Supernova seems like it should not only cause a [Game Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameOver) but destroy the entire planet given its [Overly Long Fighting Animation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverlyLongFightingAnimation) consisting of blowing up the planets of the outer Solar System and then causing a supernova that cooks the inner planets... but all it does is leave each of your party members with 1/16 of their current HP, and maybe cause some status effects. *It will never actually kill anyone.* His less grandiose attacks can do more damage and actually kill. There is a bit of [Fridge Brilliance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FridgeBrilliance) here, however. It doesn't kill you, but it *does* leave you with HP in probably the single digits, no matter how high your max HP is, and a whole cocktail of status ailments. It won't kill you, but it will leave you in despair.
[Corporate Samurai](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorporateSamurai): Prior to going rogue, he was the Shinra Corporation's greatest warrior.
[Crystal Prison](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrystalPrison): The remains of his original body were crystallized in Mako at the Northern Crater.

[Cutscene Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutsceneBoss): After defeating Safer-Sephiroth, Cloud has to duel Sephiroth in human form 1-on-1 in his mind; this is a post-game cutscene fight that cannot be lost.

[Dark and Troubled Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkAndTroubledPast): He was experimented on in the womb by his own father, being implanted with Jenova cells under the false belief it would make him a Cetra. When he was born and failed to display any power over the Lifestream, but did display supernatural strength and ability, Shinra decided to raise him as a warrior and turned him into the first SOLDIER. Shinra also lied to him about his parents, telling him that his mother was a deceased woman named Jenova.

[Dark Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsEvil): Aside from his menacing black outfit, he is associated with dark magic in general, such as the Meteor he seeks to summon and his obsession with obtaining the Black Materia. As Safer Sephiroth, though, he becomes a display of [Light Is Not Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsNotGood), though it's where he can cast [Shadow Flare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingaShadow).

[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): In *Crisis Core*, he keeps the black outfit though he is on the heroes' side as a prominent supporting character. However, since it's a prequel, we know he eventually will fall into playing the [other trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsEvil) straight.

[Dark Lord on Life Support](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkLordOnLifeSupport): He spends most of *Final Fantasy VII* missing his lower half, only kept alive by his connection to Jenova and being encased in mako crystal.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Sometimes, but not often. Best shown in this bit from Cloud's flashback:
QUOTE **Young!Cloud**: “They’ve given me a new materia. I’m so excited to try it out!”

QUOTE **Sephiroth:** “Just like a kid.”

[Defector from Decadence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefectorFromDecadence): He was considering leaving from Shinra due to growing distrust from the organization. Unfortunately, he ended up doing more than that.

[Defrosting Ice King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefrostingIceKing): At the start of *Crisis Core*, he is cold and aloof toward Zack, even dumping a mission onto him, [and this shatters Zack's image of the hero he aspired to be](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal).
